text: In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The earth was formless and empty, and darkness covered the deep waters. And the Spirit of God was hovering over the surface of the waters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let there be light,” and there was light.
speaker: God

text: And God saw that the light was good. Then he separated the light from the darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God called the light “day” and the darkness “night.”
And evening passed and morning came, marking the first day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let there be a space between the waters, to separate the waters of the heavens from the waters of the earth.”
speaker: God

text: And that is what happened. God made this space to separate the waters of the earth from the waters of the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God called the space “sky.”
And evening passed and morning came, marking the second day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let the waters beneath the sky flow together into one place, so dry ground may appear.” And that is what happened.
speaker: God

text: God called the dry ground “land” and the waters “seas.” And God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let the land sprout with vegetation—every sort of seed-bearing plant, and trees that grow seed-bearing fruit. These seeds will then produce the kinds of plants and trees from which they came.” And that is what happened.
speaker: God

text: The land produced vegetation—all sorts of seed-bearing plants, and trees with seed-bearing fruit. Their seeds produced plants and trees of the same kind. And God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: And evening passed and morning came, marking the third day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let lights appear in the sky to separate the day from the night. Let them be signs to mark the seasons, days, and years.
speaker: God

text: Let these lights in the sky shine down on the earth.” And that is what happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: God made two great lights—the larger one to govern the day, and the smaller one to govern the night. He also made the stars.
speaker: Narrator

text: God set these lights in the sky to light the earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: to govern the day and night, and to separate the light from the darkness. And God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: And evening passed and morning came, marking the fourth day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let the waters swarm with fish and other life. Let the skies be filled with birds of every kind.”
speaker: God

text: So God created great sea creatures and every living thing that scurries and swarms in the water, and every sort of bird—each producing offspring of the same kind. And God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God blessed them, saying, “Be fruitful and multiply. Let the fish fill the seas, and let the birds multiply on the earth.”
speaker: God

text: And evening passed and morning came, marking the fifth day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let the earth produce every sort of animal, each producing offspring of the same kind—livestock, small animals that scurry along the ground, and wild animals.” And that is what happened.
speaker: God

text: God made all sorts of wild animals, livestock, and small animals, each able to produce offspring of the same kind. And God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let us make human beings in our image, to be like us. They will reign over the fish in the sea, the birds in the sky, the livestock, all the wild animals on the earth, and the small animals that scurry along the ground.”
speaker: God
Narrator

text: Then God blessed them and said, “Be fruitful and multiply. Fill the earth and govern it. Reign over the fish in the sea, the birds in the sky, and all the animals that scurry along the ground.”
speaker: God

text: Then God said, “Look! I have given you every seed-bearing plant throughout the earth and all the fruit trees for your food.
speaker: God

text: And I have given every green plant as food for all the wild animals, the birds in the sky, and the small animals that scurry along the ground—everything that has life.” And that is what happened.
speaker: God

text:
Then God looked over all he had made, and he saw that it was very good!
And evening passed and morning came, marking the sixth day.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the creation of the heavens and the earth and everything in them was completed.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day God had finished his work of creation, so he rested from all his work.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God blessed the seventh day and declared it holy, because it was the day when he rested from all his work of creation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the account of the creation of the heavens and the earth.
When the Lord God made the earth and the heavens,
speaker: Narrator

text: neither wild plants nor grains were growing on the earth. For the Lord God had not yet sent rain to water the earth, and there were no people to cultivate the soil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, springs came up from the ground and watered all the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord God formed the man from the dust of the ground. He breathed the breath of life into the man’s nostrils, and the man became a living person.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord God planted a garden in Eden in the east, and there he placed the man he had made.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord God made all sorts of trees grow up from the ground—trees that were beautiful and that produced delicious fruit. In the middle of the garden he placed the tree of life and the tree of the knowledge of good and evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: A river flowed from the land of Eden, watering the garden and then dividing into four branches.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first branch, called the Pishon, flowed around the entire land of Havilah, where gold is found.
speaker: Narrator

text: The gold of that land is exceptionally pure; aromatic resin and onyx stone are also found there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The second branch, called the Gihon, flowed around the entire land of Cush.
speaker: Narrator

text: The third branch, called the Tigris, flowed east of the land of Asshur. The fourth branch is called the Euphrates.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord God placed the man in the Garden of Eden to tend and watch over it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord God warned him, “You may freely eat the fruit of every tree in the garden—
speaker: God

text: except the tree of the knowledge of good and evil. If you eat its fruit, you are sure to die.”
speaker: God

text: Then the Lord God said, “It is not good for the man to be alone. I will make a helper who is just right for him.”
speaker: God

text: So the Lord God formed from the ground all the wild animals and all the birds of the sky. He brought them to the man to see what he would call them, and the man chose a name for each one.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave names to all the livestock, all the birds of the sky, and all the wild animals. But still there was no helper just right for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord God caused the man to fall into a deep sleep. While the man slept, the Lord God took out one of the man’s ribs and closed up the opening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord God made a woman from the rib, and he brought her to the man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“At last!” the man exclaimed.
“This one is bone from my bone,
    and flesh from my flesh!
She will be called ‘woman,’
    because she was taken from ‘man.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: This explains why a man leaves his father and mother and is joined to his wife, and the two are united into one.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the man and his wife were both naked, but they felt no shame.
speaker: Narrator

text: The serpent was the shrewdest of all the wild animals the Lord God had made. One day he asked the woman, “Did God really say you must not eat the fruit from any of the trees in the garden?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Of course we may eat fruit from the trees in the garden,” the woman replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: “It’s only the fruit from the tree in the middle of the garden that we are not allowed to eat. God said, ‘You must not eat it or even touch it; if you do, you will die.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You won’t die!” the serpent replied to the woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: “God knows that your eyes will be opened as soon as you eat it, and you will be like God, knowing both good and evil.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman was convinced. She saw that the tree was beautiful and its fruit looked delicious, and she wanted the wisdom it would give her. So she took some of the fruit and ate it. Then she gave some to her husband, who was with her, and he ate it, too.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that moment their eyes were opened, and they suddenly felt shame at their nakedness. So they sewed fig leaves together to cover themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the cool evening breezes were blowing, the man and his wife heard the Lord God walking about in the garden. So they hid from the Lord God among the trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord God called to the man, “Where are you?”
speaker: God

text: He replied, “I heard you walking in the garden, so I hid. I was afraid because I was naked.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Who told you that you were naked?” the Lord God asked. “Have you eaten from the tree whose fruit I commanded you not to eat?”
speaker: God

text: The man replied, “It was the woman you gave me who gave me the fruit, and I ate it.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Lord God asked the woman, “What have you done?”
“The serpent deceived me,” she replied. “That’s why I ate it.”
speaker: God

text:
Then the Lord God said to the serpent,
“Because you have done this, you are cursed
    more than all animals, domestic and wild.
You will crawl on your belly,
    groveling in the dust as long as you live.
speaker: God

text:
And I will cause hostility between you and the woman,
    and between your offspring and her offspring.
He will strike your head,
    and you will strike his heel.”
speaker: God

text:
Then he said to the woman,
“I will sharpen the pain of your pregnancy,
    and in pain you will give birth.
And you will desire to control your husband,
    but he will rule over you.”
speaker: God

text:
And to the man he said,
“Since you listened to your wife and ate from the tree
    whose fruit I commanded you not to eat,
the ground is cursed because of you.
    All your life you will struggle to scratch a living from it.
speaker: God

text:
It will grow thorns and thistles for you,
    though you will eat of its grains.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By the sweat of your brow
    will you have food to eat
until you return to the ground
    from which you were made.
For you were made from dust,
    and to dust you will return.”
speaker: God

text: Then the man—Adam—named his wife Eve, because she would be the mother of all who live.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord God made clothing from animal skins for Adam and his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord God said, “Look, the human beings have become like us, knowing both good and evil. What if they reach out, take fruit from the tree of life, and eat it? Then they will live forever!”
speaker: God

text: So the Lord God banished them from the Garden of Eden, and he sent Adam out to cultivate the ground from which he had been made.
speaker: God

text: After sending them out, the Lord God stationed mighty cherubim to the east of the Garden of Eden. And he placed a flaming sword that flashed back and forth to guard the way to the tree of life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Adam had sexual relations with his wife, Eve, and she became pregnant. When she gave birth to Cain, she said, “With the Lord’s help, I have produced a man!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Later she gave birth to his brother and named him Abel.
When they grew up, Abel became a shepherd, while Cain cultivated the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was time for the harvest, Cain presented some of his crops as a gift to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abel also brought a gift—the best portions of the firstborn lambs from his flock. The Lord accepted Abel and his gift,
speaker: Narrator

text: but he did not accept Cain and his gift. This made Cain very angry, and he looked dejected.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why are you so angry?” the Lord asked Cain. “Why do you look so dejected?
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be accepted if you do what is right. But if you refuse to do what is right, then watch out! Sin is crouching at the door, eager to control you. But you must subdue it and be its master.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Cain suggested to his brother, “Let’s go out into the fields.” And while they were in the field, Cain attacked his brother, Abel, and killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Afterward the Lord asked Cain, “Where is your brother? Where is Abel?”
“I don’t know,” Cain responded. “Am I my brother’s guardian?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said, “What have you done? Listen! Your brother’s blood cries out to me from the ground!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you are cursed and banished from the ground, which has swallowed your brother’s blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: No longer will the ground yield good crops for you, no matter how hard you work! From now on you will be a homeless wanderer on the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Cain replied to the Lord, “My punishment is too great for me to bear!
speaker: Narrator

text: You have banished me from the land and from your presence; you have made me a homeless wanderer. Anyone who finds me will kill me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord replied, “No, for I will give a sevenfold punishment to anyone who kills you.” Then the Lord put a mark on Cain to warn anyone who might try to kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Cain left the Lord’s presence and settled in the land of Nod, east of Eden.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cain had sexual relations with his wife, and she became pregnant and gave birth to Enoch. Then Cain founded a city, which he named Enoch, after his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Enoch had a son named Irad. Irad became the father of Mehujael. Mehujael became the father of Methushael. Methushael became the father of Lamech.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lamech married two women. The first was named Adah, and the second was Zillah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adah gave birth to Jabal, who was the first of those who raise livestock and live in tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: His brother’s name was Jubal, the first of all who play the harp and flute.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lamech’s other wife, Zillah, gave birth to a son named Tubal-cain. He became an expert in forging tools of bronze and iron. Tubal-cain had a sister named Naamah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One day Lamech said to his wives,
“Adah and Zillah, hear my voice;
    listen to me, you wives of Lamech.
I have killed a man who attacked me,
    a young man who wounded me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If someone who kills Cain is punished seven times,
    then the one who kills me will be punished seventy-seven times!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Adam had sexual relations with his wife again, and she gave birth to another son. She named him Seth, for she said, “God has granted me another son in place of Abel, whom Cain killed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Seth grew up, he had a son and named him Enosh. At that time people first began to worship the Lord by name.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the written account of the descendants of Adam. When God created human beings, he made them to be like himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: He created them male and female, and he blessed them and called them “human.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Adam was 130 years old, he became the father of a son who was just like him—in his very image. He named his son Seth.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the birth of Seth, Adam lived another 800 years, and he had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adam lived 930 years, and then he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Seth was 105 years old, he became the father of Enosh.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the birth of Enosh, Seth lived another 807 years, and he had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seth lived 912 years, and then he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Enosh was 90 years old, he became the father of Kenan.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the birth of Kenan, Enosh lived another 815 years, and he had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Enosh lived 905 years, and then he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Kenan was 70 years old, he became the father of Mahalalel.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the birth of Mahalalel, Kenan lived another 840 years, and he had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kenan lived 910 years, and then he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Mahalalel was 65 years old, he became the father of Jared.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the birth of Jared, Mahalalel lived another 830 years, and he had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mahalalel lived 895 years, and then he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jared was 162 years old, he became the father of Enoch.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the birth of Enoch, Jared lived another 800 years, and he had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jared lived 962 years, and then he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Enoch was 65 years old, he became the father of Methuselah.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the birth of Methuselah, Enoch lived in close fellowship with God for another 300 years, and he had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Enoch lived 365 years,
speaker: Narrator

text: walking in close fellowship with God. Then one day he disappeared, because God took him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Methuselah was 187 years old, he became the father of Lamech.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the birth of Lamech, Methuselah lived another 782 years, and he had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Methuselah lived 969 years, and then he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Lamech was 182 years old, he became the father of a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lamech named his son Noah, for he said, “May he bring us relief from our work and the painful labor of farming this ground that the Lord has cursed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After the birth of Noah, Lamech lived another 595 years, and he had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lamech lived 777 years, and then he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Noah was 500 years old, he became the father of Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people began to multiply on the earth, and daughters were born to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of God saw the beautiful women and took any they wanted as their wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said, “My Spirit will not put up with humans for such a long time, for they are only mortal flesh. In the future, their normal lifespan will be no more than 120 years.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days, and for some time after, giant Nephilites lived on the earth, for whenever the sons of God had intercourse with women, they gave birth to children who became the heroes and famous warriors of ancient times.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord observed the extent of human wickedness on the earth, and he saw that everything they thought or imagined was consistently and totally evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord was sorry he had ever made them and put them on the earth. It broke his heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said, “I will wipe this human race I have created from the face of the earth. Yes, and I will destroy every living thing—all the people, the large animals, the small animals that scurry along the ground, and even the birds of the sky. I am sorry I ever made them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Noah found favor with the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the account of Noah and his family. Noah was a righteous man, the only blameless person living on earth at the time, and he walked in close fellowship with God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah was the father of three sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now God saw that the earth had become corrupt and was filled with violence.
speaker: Narrator

text: God observed all this corruption in the world, for everyone on earth was corrupt.
speaker: Narrator

text: So God said to Noah, “I have decided to destroy all living creatures, for they have filled the earth with violence. Yes, I will wipe them all out along with the earth!
speaker: Narrator

text: “Build a large boat from cypress wood and waterproof it with tar, inside and out. Then construct decks and stalls throughout its interior.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make the boat 450 feet long, 75 feet wide, and 45 feet high.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leave an 18-inch opening below the roof all the way around the boat. Put the door on the side, and build three decks inside the boat—lower, middle, and upper.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look! I am about to cover the earth with a flood that will destroy every living thing that breathes. Everything on earth will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will confirm my covenant with you. So enter the boat—you and your wife and your sons and their wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring a pair of every kind of animal—a male and a female—into the boat with you to keep them alive during the flood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pairs of every kind of bird, and every kind of animal, and every kind of small animal that scurries along the ground, will come to you to be kept alive.
speaker: Narrator

text: And be sure to take on board enough food for your family and for all the animals.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Noah did everything exactly as God had commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When everything was ready, the Lord said to Noah, “Go into the boat with all your family, for among all the people of the earth, I can see that you alone are righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take with you seven pairs—male and female—of each animal I have approved for eating and for sacrifice, and take one pair of each of the others.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also take seven pairs of every kind of bird. There must be a male and a female in each pair to ensure that all life will survive on the earth after the flood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seven days from now I will make the rains pour down on the earth. And it will rain for forty days and forty nights, until I have wiped from the earth all the living things I have created.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Noah did everything as the Lord commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah was 600 years old when the flood covered the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went on board the boat to escape the flood—he and his wife and his sons and their wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: With them were all the various kinds of animals—those approved for eating and for sacrifice and those that were not—along with all the birds and the small animals that scurry along the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: They entered the boat in pairs, male and female, just as God had commanded Noah.
speaker: Narrator

text: After seven days, the waters of the flood came and covered the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Noah was 600 years old, on the seventeenth day of the second month, all the underground waters erupted from the earth, and the rain fell in mighty torrents from the sky.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rain continued to fall for forty days and forty nights.
speaker: Narrator

text: That very day Noah had gone into the boat with his wife and his sons—Shem, Ham, and Japheth—and their wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: With them in the boat were pairs of every kind of animal—domestic and wild, large and small—along with birds of every kind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two by two they came into the boat, representing every living thing that breathes.
speaker: Narrator

text: A male and female of each kind entered, just as God had commanded Noah. Then the Lord closed the door behind them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For forty days the floodwaters grew deeper, covering the ground and lifting the boat high above the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the waters rose higher and higher above the ground, the boat floated safely on the surface.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, the water covered even the highest mountains on the earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: rising more than twenty-two feet above the highest peaks.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the living things on earth died—birds, domestic animals, wild animals, small animals that scurry along the ground, and all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything that breathed and lived on dry land died.
speaker: Narrator

text: God wiped out every living thing on the earth—people, livestock, small animals that scurry along the ground, and the birds of the sky. All were destroyed. The only people who survived were Noah and those with him in the boat.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the floodwaters covered the earth for 150 days.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God remembered Noah and all the wild animals and livestock with him in the boat. He sent a wind to blow across the earth, and the floodwaters began to recede.
speaker: Narrator

text: The underground waters stopped flowing, and the torrential rains from the sky were stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the floodwaters gradually receded from the earth. After 150 days,
speaker: Narrator

text: exactly five months from the time the flood began, the boat came to rest on the mountains of Ararat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two and a half months later, as the waters continued to go down, other mountain peaks became visible.
speaker: Narrator

text: After another forty days, Noah opened the window he had made in the boat
speaker: Narrator

text: and released a raven. The bird flew back and forth until the floodwaters on the earth had dried up.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also released a dove to see if the water had receded and it could find dry ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the dove could find no place to land because the water still covered the ground. So it returned to the boat, and Noah held out his hand and drew the dove back inside.
speaker: Narrator

text: After waiting another seven days, Noah released the dove again.
speaker: Narrator

text: This time the dove returned to him in the evening with a fresh olive leaf in its beak. Then Noah knew that the floodwaters were almost gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: He waited another seven days and then released the dove again. This time it did not come back.
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah was now 601 years old. On the first day of the new year, ten and a half months after the flood began, the floodwaters had almost dried up from the earth. Noah lifted back the covering of the boat and saw that the surface of the ground was drying.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two more months went by, and at last the earth was dry!
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said to Noah,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Leave the boat, all of you—you and your wife, and your sons and their wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Release all the animals—the birds, the livestock, and the small animals that scurry along the ground—so they can be fruitful and multiply throughout the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Noah, his wife, and his sons and their wives left the boat.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all of the large and small animals and birds came out of the boat, pair by pair.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Noah built an altar to the Lord, and there he sacrificed as burnt offerings the animals and birds that had been approved for that purpose.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord was pleased with the aroma of the sacrifice and said to himself, “I will never again curse the ground because of the human race, even though everything they think or imagine is bent toward evil from childhood. I will never again destroy all living things.
speaker: Narrator

text: As long as the earth remains, there will be planting and harvest, cold and heat, summer and winter, day and night.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God blessed Noah and his sons and told them, “Be fruitful and multiply. Fill the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the animals of the earth, all the birds of the sky, all the small animals that scurry along the ground, and all the fish in the sea will look on you with fear and terror. I have placed them in your power.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have given them to you for food, just as I have given you grain and vegetables.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must never eat any meat that still has the lifeblood in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And I will require the blood of anyone who takes another person’s life. If a wild animal kills a person, it must die. And anyone who murders a fellow human must die.
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone takes a human life, that person’s life will also be taken by human hands. For God made human beings in his own image.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now be fruitful and multiply, and repopulate the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God told Noah and his sons,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I hereby confirm my covenant with you and your descendants,
speaker: Narrator

text: and with all the animals that were on the boat with you—the birds, the livestock, and all the wild animals—every living creature on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, I am confirming my covenant with you. Never again will floodwaters kill all living creatures; never again will a flood destroy the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “I am giving you a sign of my covenant with you and with all living creatures, for all generations to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have placed my rainbow in the clouds. It is the sign of my covenant with you and with all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I send clouds over the earth, the rainbow will appear in the clouds,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I will remember my covenant with you and with all living creatures. Never again will the floodwaters destroy all life.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I see the rainbow in the clouds, I will remember the eternal covenant between God and every living creature on earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said to Noah, “Yes, this rainbow is the sign of the covenant I am confirming with all the creatures on earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Noah who came out of the boat with their father were Shem, Ham, and Japheth. (Ham is the father of Canaan.)
speaker: Narrator

text: From these three sons of Noah came all the people who now populate the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the flood, Noah began to cultivate the ground, and he planted a vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day he drank some wine he had made, and he became drunk and lay naked inside his tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ham, the father of Canaan, saw that his father was naked and went outside and told his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Shem and Japheth took a robe, held it over their shoulders, and backed into the tent to cover their father. As they did this, they looked the other way so they would not see him naked.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Noah woke up from his stupor, he learned what Ham, his youngest son, had done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he cursed Canaan, the son of Ham:
“May Canaan be cursed!
    May he be the lowest of servants to his relatives.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Noah said,
“May the Lord, the God of Shem, be blessed,
    and may Canaan be his servant!
speaker: Narrator

text:
May God expand the territory of Japheth!
May Japheth share the prosperity of Shem,
    and may Canaan be his servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah lived another 350 years after the great flood.
speaker: Narrator

text: He lived 950 years, and then he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the account of the families of Shem, Ham, and Japheth, the three sons of Noah. Many children were born to them after the great flood.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Japheth were Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Gomer were Ashkenaz, Riphath, and Togarmah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Javan were Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim, and Rodanim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their descendants became the seafaring peoples that spread out to various lands, each identified by its own language, clan, and national identity.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Ham were Cush, Mizraim, Put, and Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Cush were Seba, Havilah, Sabtah, Raamah, and Sabteca. The descendants of Raamah were Sheba and Dedan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cush was also the ancestor of Nimrod, who was the first heroic warrior on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since he was the greatest hunter in the world, his name became proverbial. People would say, “This man is like Nimrod, the greatest hunter in the world.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He built his kingdom in the land of Babylonia, with the cities of Babylon, Erech, Akkad, and Calneh.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there he expanded his territory to Assyria, building the cities of Nineveh, Rehoboth-ir, Calah,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Resen (the great city located between Nineveh and Calah).
speaker: Narrator

text: Mizraim was the ancestor of the Ludites, Anamites, Lehabites, Naphtuhites,
speaker: Narrator

text: Pathrusites, Casluhites, and the Caphtorites, from whom the Philistines came.
speaker: Narrator

text: Canaan’s oldest son was Sidon, the ancestor of the Sidonians. Canaan was also the ancestor of the Hittites,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jebusites, Amorites, Girgashites,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hivites, Arkites, Sinites,
speaker: Narrator

text: Arvadites, Zemarites, and Hamathites. The Canaanite clans eventually spread out,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the territory of Canaan extended from Sidon in the north to Gerar and Gaza in the south, and east as far as Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, and Zeboiim, near Lasha.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the descendants of Ham, identified by clan, language, territory, and national identity.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sons were also born to Shem, the older brother of Japheth. Shem was the ancestor of all the descendants of Eber.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Shem were Elam, Asshur, Arphaxad, Lud, and Aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Aram were Uz, Hul, Gether, and Mash.
speaker: Narrator

text: Arphaxad was the father of Shelah, and Shelah was the father of Eber.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eber had two sons. The first was named Peleg (which means “division”), for during his lifetime the people of the world were divided into different language groups. His brother’s name was Joktan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joktan was the ancestor of Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Obal, Abimael, Sheba,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab. All these were descendants of Joktan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The territory they occupied extended from Mesha all the way to Sephar in the eastern mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the descendants of Shem, identified by clan, language, territory, and national identity.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the clans that descended from Noah’s sons, arranged by nation according to their lines of descent. All the nations of the earth descended from these clans after the great flood.
speaker: Narrator

text: At one time all the people of the world spoke the same language and used the same words.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the people migrated to the east, they found a plain in the land of Babylonia and settled there.
speaker: Narrator

text: They began saying to each other, “Let’s make bricks and harden them with fire.” (In this region bricks were used instead of stone, and tar was used for mortar.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said, “Come, let’s build a great city for ourselves with a tower that reaches into the sky. This will make us famous and keep us from being scattered all over the world.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord came down to look at the city and the tower the people were building.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look!” he said. “The people are united, and they all speak the same language. After this, nothing they set out to do will be impossible for them!
speaker: Narrator

text: Come, let’s go down and confuse the people with different languages. Then they won’t be able to understand each other.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In that way, the Lord scattered them all over the world, and they stopped building the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why the city was called Babel, because that is where the Lord confused the people with different languages. In this way he scattered them all over the world.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the account of Shem’s family.
Two years after the great flood, when Shem was 100 years old, he became the father of Arphaxad.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the birth of Arphaxad, Shem lived another 500 years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Arphaxad was 35 years old, he became the father of Shelah.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the birth of Shelah, Arphaxad lived another 403 years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Shelah was 30 years old, he became the father of Eber.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the birth of Eber, Shelah lived another 403 years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Eber was 34 years old, he became the father of Peleg.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the birth of Peleg, Eber lived another 430 years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Peleg was 30 years old, he became the father of Reu.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the birth of Reu, Peleg lived another 209 years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Reu was 32 years old, he became the father of Serug.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the birth of Serug, Reu lived another 207 years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Serug was 30 years old, he became the father of Nahor.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the birth of Nahor, Serug lived another 200 years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Nahor was 29 years old, he became the father of Terah.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the birth of Terah, Nahor lived another 119 years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Terah was 70 years old, he became the father of Abram, Nahor, and Haran.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the account of Terah’s family. Terah was the father of Abram, Nahor, and Haran; and Haran was the father of Lot.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Haran died in Ur of the Chaldeans, the land of his birth, while his father, Terah, was still living.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Abram and Nahor both married. The name of Abram’s wife was Sarai, and the name of Nahor’s wife was Milcah. (Milcah and her sister Iscah were daughters of Nahor’s brother Haran.)
speaker: Narrator

text: But Sarai was unable to become pregnant and had no children.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Terah took his son Abram, his daughter-in-law Sarai (his son Abram’s wife), and his grandson Lot (his son Haran’s child) and moved away from Ur of the Chaldeans. He was headed for the land of Canaan, but they stopped at Haran and settled there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Terah lived for 205 years and died while still in Haran.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord had said to Abram, “Leave your native country, your relatives, and your father’s family, and go to the land that I will show you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make you into a great nation. I will bless you and make you famous, and you will be a blessing to others.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bless those who bless you and curse those who treat you with contempt. All the families on earth will be blessed through you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram departed as the Lord had instructed, and Lot went with him. Abram was seventy-five years old when he left Haran.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took his wife, Sarai, his nephew Lot, and all his wealth—his livestock and all the people he had taken into his household at Haran—and headed for the land of Canaan. When they arrived in Canaan,
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram traveled through the land as far as Shechem. There he set up camp beside the oak of Moreh. At that time, the area was inhabited by Canaanites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord appeared to Abram and said, “I will give this land to your descendants.” And Abram built an altar there and dedicated it to the Lord, who had appeared to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that, Abram traveled south and set up camp in the hill country, with Bethel to the west and Ai to the east. There he built another altar and dedicated it to the Lord, and he worshiped the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abram continued traveling south by stages toward the Negev.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time a severe famine struck the land of Canaan, forcing Abram to go down to Egypt, where he lived as a foreigner.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he was approaching the border of Egypt, Abram said to his wife, Sarai, “Look, you are a very beautiful woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Egyptians see you, they will say, ‘This is his wife. Let’s kill him; then we can have her!’
speaker: Narrator

text: So please tell them you are my sister. Then they will spare my life and treat me well because of their interest in you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And sure enough, when Abram arrived in Egypt, everyone noticed Sarai’s beauty.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the palace officials saw her, they sang her praises to Pharaoh, their king, and Sarai was taken into his palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh gave Abram many gifts because of her—sheep, goats, cattle, male and female donkeys, male and female servants, and camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord sent terrible plagues upon Pharaoh and his household because of Sarai, Abram’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Pharaoh summoned Abram and accused him sharply. “What have you done to me?” he demanded. “Why didn’t you tell me she was your wife?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why did you say, ‘She is my sister,’ and allow me to take her as my wife? Now then, here is your wife. Take her and get out of here!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh ordered some of his men to escort them, and he sent Abram out of the country, along with his wife and all his possessions.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram left Egypt and traveled north into the Negev, along with his wife and Lot and all that they owned.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Abram was very rich in livestock, silver, and gold.)
speaker: Narrator

text: From the Negev, they continued traveling by stages toward Bethel, and they pitched their tents between Bethel and Ai, where they had camped before.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the same place where Abram had built the altar, and there he worshiped the Lord again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lot, who was traveling with Abram, had also become very wealthy with flocks of sheep and goats, herds of cattle, and many tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the land could not support both Abram and Lot with all their flocks and herds living so close together.
speaker: Narrator

text: So disputes broke out between the herdsmen of Abram and Lot. (At that time Canaanites and Perizzites were also living in the land.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally Abram said to Lot, “Let’s not allow this conflict to come between us or our herdsmen. After all, we are close relatives!
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole countryside is open to you. Take your choice of any section of the land you want, and we will separate. If you want the land to the left, then I’ll take the land on the right. If you prefer the land on the right, then I’ll go to the left.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Lot took a long look at the fertile plains of the Jordan Valley in the direction of Zoar. The whole area was well watered everywhere, like the garden of the Lord or the beautiful land of Egypt. (This was before the Lord destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Lot chose for himself the whole Jordan Valley to the east of them. He went there with his flocks and servants and parted company with his uncle Abram.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram settled in the land of Canaan, and Lot moved his tents to a place near Sodom and settled among the cities of the plain.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people of this area were extremely wicked and constantly sinned against the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Lot had gone, the Lord said to Abram, “Look as far as you can see in every direction—north and south, east and west.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am giving all this land, as far as you can see, to you and your descendants as a permanent possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will give you so many descendants that, like the dust of the earth, they cannot be counted!
speaker: Narrator

text: Go and walk through the land in every direction, for I am giving it to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram moved his camp to Hebron and settled near the oak grove belonging to Mamre. There he built another altar to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: About this time war broke out in the region. King Amraphel of Babylonia, King Arioch of Ellasar, King Kedorlaomer of Elam, and King Tidal of Goiim
speaker: Narrator

text: fought against King Bera of Sodom, King Birsha of Gomorrah, King Shinab of Admah, King Shemeber of Zeboiim, and the king of Bela (also called Zoar).
speaker: Narrator

text: This second group of kings joined forces in Siddim Valley (that is, the valley of the Dead Sea).
speaker: Narrator

text: For twelve years they had been subject to King Kedorlaomer, but in the thirteenth year they rebelled against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: One year later Kedorlaomer and his allies arrived and defeated the Rephaites at Ashteroth-karnaim, the Zuzites at Ham, the Emites at Shaveh-kiriathaim,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Horites at Mount Seir, as far as El-paran at the edge of the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they turned back and came to En-mishpat (now called Kadesh) and conquered all the territory of the Amalekites, and also the Amorites living in Hazazon-tamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the rebel kings of Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, Zeboiim, and Bela (also called Zoar) prepared for battle in the valley of the Dead Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: They fought against King Kedorlaomer of Elam, King Tidal of Goiim, King Amraphel of Babylonia, and King Arioch of Ellasar—four kings against five.
speaker: Narrator

text: As it happened, the valley of the Dead Sea was filled with tar pits. And as the army of the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah fled, some fell into the tar pits, while the rest escaped into the mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text: The victorious invaders then plundered Sodom and Gomorrah and headed for home, taking with them all the spoils of war and the food supplies.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also captured Lot—Abram’s nephew who lived in Sodom—and carried off everything he owned.
speaker: Narrator

text: But one of Lot’s men escaped and reported everything to Abram the Hebrew, who was living near the oak grove belonging to Mamre the Amorite. Mamre and his relatives, Eshcol and Aner, were Abram’s allies.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abram heard that his nephew Lot had been captured, he mobilized the 318 trained men who had been born into his household. Then he pursued Kedorlaomer’s army until he caught up with them at Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: There he divided his men and attacked during the night. Kedorlaomer’s army fled, but Abram chased them as far as Hobah, north of Damascus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram recovered all the goods that had been taken, and he brought back his nephew Lot with his possessions and all the women and other captives.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Abram returned from his victory over Kedorlaomer and all his allies, the king of Sodom went out to meet him in the valley of Shaveh (that is, the King’s Valley).
speaker: Narrator

text: And Melchizedek, the king of Salem and a priest of God Most High, brought Abram some bread and wine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Melchizedek blessed Abram with this blessing:
“Blessed be Abram by God Most High,
    Creator of heaven and earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And blessed be God Most High,
    who has defeated your enemies for you.”
Then Abram gave Melchizedek a tenth of all the goods he had recovered.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Sodom said to Abram, “Give back my people who were captured. But you may keep for yourself all the goods you have recovered.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram replied to the king of Sodom, “I solemnly swear to the Lord, God Most High, Creator of heaven and earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: that I will not take so much as a single thread or sandal thong from what belongs to you. Otherwise you might say, ‘I am the one who made Abram rich.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I will accept only what my young warriors have already eaten, and I request that you give a fair share of the goods to my allies—Aner, Eshcol, and Mamre.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, the Lord spoke to Abram in a vision and said to him, “Do not be afraid, Abram, for I will protect you, and your reward will be great.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abram replied, “O Sovereign Lord, what good are all your blessings when I don’t even have a son? Since you’ve given me no children, Eliezer of Damascus, a servant in my household, will inherit all my wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have given me no descendants of my own, so one of my servants will be my heir.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to him, “No, your servant will not be your heir, for you will have a son of your own who will be your heir.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord took Abram outside and said to him, “Look up into the sky and count the stars if you can. That’s how many descendants you will have!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abram believed the Lord, and the Lord counted him as righteous because of his faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord told him, “I am the Lord who brought you out of Ur of the Chaldeans to give you this land as your possession.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abram replied, “O Sovereign Lord, how can I be sure that I will actually possess it?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told him, “Bring me a three-year-old heifer, a three-year-old female goat, a three-year-old ram, a turtledove, and a young pigeon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram presented all these to him and killed them. Then he cut each animal down the middle and laid the halves side by side; he did not, however, cut the birds in half.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some vultures swooped down to eat the carcasses, but Abram chased them away.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the sun was going down, Abram fell into a deep sleep, and a terrifying darkness came down over him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Abram, “You can be sure that your descendants will be strangers in a foreign land, where they will be oppressed as slaves for 400 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will punish the nation that enslaves them, and in the end they will come away with great wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text: (As for you, you will die in peace and be buried at a ripe old age.)
speaker: Narrator

text: After four generations your descendants will return here to this land, for the sins of the Amorites do not yet warrant their destruction.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After the sun went down and darkness fell, Abram saw a smoking firepot and a flaming torch pass between the halves of the carcasses.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord made a covenant with Abram that day and said, “I have given this land to your descendants, all the way from the border of Egypt to the great Euphrates River—
speaker: Narrator

text: the land now occupied by the Kenites, Kenizzites, Kadmonites,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hittites, Perizzites, Rephaites,
speaker: Narrator

text: Amorites, Canaanites, Girgashites, and Jebusites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Sarai, Abram’s wife, had not been able to bear children for him. But she had an Egyptian servant named Hagar.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Sarai said to Abram, “The Lord has prevented me from having children. Go and sleep with my servant. Perhaps I can have children through her.” And Abram agreed with Sarai’s proposal.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Sarai, Abram’s wife, took Hagar the Egyptian servant and gave her to Abram as a wife. (This happened ten years after Abram had settled in the land of Canaan.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram had sexual relations with Hagar, and she became pregnant. But when Hagar knew she was pregnant, she began to treat her mistress, Sarai, with contempt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Sarai said to Abram, “This is all your fault! I put my servant into your arms, but now that she’s pregnant she treats me with contempt. The Lord will show who’s wrong—you or me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram replied, “Look, she is your servant, so deal with her as you see fit.” Then Sarai treated Hagar so harshly that she finally ran away.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord found Hagar beside a spring of water in the wilderness, along the road to Shur.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The angel said to her, “Hagar, Sarai’s servant, where have you come from, and where are you going?”
“I’m running away from my mistress, Sarai,” she replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord said to her, “Return to your mistress, and submit to her authority.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he added, “I will give you more descendants than you can count.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the angel also said, “You are now pregnant and will give birth to a son. You are to name him Ishmael (which means ‘God hears’), for the Lord has heard your cry of distress.
speaker: Narrator

text: This son of yours will be a wild man, as untamed as a wild donkey! He will raise his fist against everyone, and everyone will be against him. Yes, he will live in open hostility against all his relatives.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Thereafter, Hagar used another name to refer to the Lord, who had spoken to her. She said, “You are the God who sees me.” She also said, “Have I truly seen the One who sees me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So that well was named Beer-lahai-roi (which means “well of the Living One who sees me”). It can still be found between Kadesh and Bered.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hagar gave Abram a son, and Abram named him Ishmael.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram was eighty-six years old when Ishmael was born.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abram was ninety-nine years old, the Lord appeared to him and said, “I am El-Shaddai—‘God Almighty.’ Serve me faithfully and live a blameless life.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make a covenant with you, by which I will guarantee to give you countless descendants.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, Abram fell face down on the ground. Then God said to him,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is my covenant with you: I will make you the father of a multitude of nations!
speaker: Narrator

text: What’s more, I am changing your name. It will no longer be Abram. Instead, you will be called Abraham, for you will be the father of many nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make you extremely fruitful. Your descendants will become many nations, and kings will be among them!
speaker: Narrator

text: “I will confirm my covenant with you and your descendants after you, from generation to generation. This is the everlasting covenant: I will always be your God and the God of your descendants after you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will give the entire land of Canaan, where you now live as a foreigner, to you and your descendants. It will be their possession forever, and I will be their God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said to Abraham, “Your responsibility is to obey the terms of the covenant. You and all your descendants have this continual responsibility.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the covenant that you and your descendants must keep: Each male among you must be circumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must cut off the flesh of your foreskin as a sign of the covenant between me and you.
speaker: Narrator

text: From generation to generation, every male child must be circumcised on the eighth day after his birth. This applies not only to members of your family but also to the servants born in your household and the foreign-born servants whom you have purchased.
speaker: Narrator

text: All must be circumcised. Your bodies will bear the mark of my everlasting covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any male who fails to be circumcised will be cut off from the covenant family for breaking the covenant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said to Abraham, “Regarding Sarai, your wife—her name will no longer be Sarai. From now on her name will be Sarah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will bless her and give you a son from her! Yes, I will bless her richly, and she will become the mother of many nations. Kings of nations will be among her descendants.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham bowed down to the ground, but he laughed to himself in disbelief. “How could I become a father at the age of 100?” he thought. “And how can Sarah have a baby when she is ninety years old?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham said to God, “May Ishmael live under your special blessing!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But God replied, “No—Sarah, your wife, will give birth to a son for you. You will name him Isaac, and I will confirm my covenant with him and his descendants as an everlasting covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for Ishmael, I will bless him also, just as you have asked. I will make him extremely fruitful and multiply his descendants. He will become the father of twelve princes, and I will make him a great nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: But my covenant will be confirmed with Isaac, who will be born to you and Sarah about this time next year.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When God had finished speaking, he left Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that very day Abraham took his son, Ishmael, and every male in his household, including those born there and those he had bought. Then he circumcised them, cutting off their foreskins, just as God had told him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham was ninety-nine years old when he was circumcised,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Ishmael, his son, was thirteen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Both Abraham and his son, Ishmael, were circumcised on that same day,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with all the other men and boys of the household, whether they were born there or bought as servants. All were circumcised with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord appeared again to Abraham near the oak grove belonging to Mamre. One day Abraham was sitting at the entrance to his tent during the hottest part of the day.
speaker: Narrator

text: He looked up and noticed three men standing nearby. When he saw them, he ran to meet them and welcomed them, bowing low to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: “My lord,” he said, “if it pleases you, stop here for a while.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rest in the shade of this tree while water is brought to wash your feet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And since you’ve honored your servant with this visit, let me prepare some food to refresh you before you continue on your journey.”
“All right,” they said. “Do as you have said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham ran back to the tent and said to Sarah, “Hurry! Get three large measures of your best flour, knead it into dough, and bake some bread.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham ran out to the herd and chose a tender calf and gave it to his servant, who quickly prepared it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the food was ready, Abraham took some yogurt and milk and the roasted meat, and he served it to the men. As they ate, Abraham waited on them in the shade of the trees.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where is Sarah, your wife?” the visitors asked.
“She’s inside the tent,” Abraham replied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then one of them said, “I will return to you about this time next year, and your wife, Sarah, will have a son!”
Sarah was listening to this conversation from the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham and Sarah were both very old by this time, and Sarah was long past the age of having children.
speaker: Narrator

text: So she laughed silently to herself and said, “How could a worn-out woman like me enjoy such pleasure, especially when my master—my husband—is also so old?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Abraham, “Why did Sarah laugh? Why did she say, ‘Can an old woman like me have a baby?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Is anything too hard for the Lord? I will return about this time next year, and Sarah will have a son.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sarah was afraid, so she denied it, saying, “I didn’t laugh.”
But the Lord said, “No, you did laugh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men got up from their meal and looked out toward Sodom. As they left, Abraham went with them to send them on their way.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Should I hide my plan from Abraham?” the Lord asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For Abraham will certainly become a great and mighty nation, and all the nations of the earth will be blessed through him.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have singled him out so that he will direct his sons and their families to keep the way of the Lord by doing what is right and just. Then I will do for Abraham all that I have promised.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord told Abraham, “I have heard a great outcry from Sodom and Gomorrah, because their sin is so flagrant.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am going down to see if their actions are as wicked as I have heard. If not, I want to know.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The other men turned and headed toward Sodom, but the Lord remained with Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham approached him and said, “Will you sweep away both the righteous and the wicked?
speaker: Narrator

text: Suppose you find fifty righteous people living there in the city—will you still sweep it away and not spare it for their sakes?
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely you wouldn’t do such a thing, destroying the righteous along with the wicked. Why, you would be treating the righteous and the wicked exactly the same! Surely you wouldn’t do that! Should not the Judge of all the earth do what is right?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord replied, “If I find fifty righteous people in Sodom, I will spare the entire city for their sake.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham spoke again. “Since I have begun, let me speak further to my Lord, even though I am but dust and ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Suppose there are only forty-five righteous people rather than fifty? Will you destroy the whole city for lack of five?”
And the Lord said, “I will not destroy it if I find forty-five righteous people there.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Abraham pressed his request further. “Suppose there are only forty?”
And the Lord replied, “I will not destroy it for the sake of the forty.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Please don’t be angry, my Lord,” Abraham pleaded. “Let me speak—suppose only thirty righteous people are found?”
And the Lord replied, “I will not destroy it if I find thirty.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Abraham said, “Since I have dared to speak to the Lord, let me continue—suppose there are only twenty?”
And the Lord replied, “Then I will not destroy it for the sake of the twenty.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Finally, Abraham said, “Lord, please don’t be angry with me if I speak one more time. Suppose only ten are found there?”
And the Lord replied, “Then I will not destroy it for the sake of the ten.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord had finished his conversation with Abraham, he went on his way, and Abraham returned to his tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: That evening the two angels came to the entrance of the city of Sodom. Lot was sitting there, and when he saw them, he stood up to meet them. Then he welcomed them and bowed with his face to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My lords,” he said, “come to my home to wash your feet, and be my guests for the night. You may then get up early in the morning and be on your way again.”
“Oh no,” they replied. “We’ll just spend the night out here in the city square.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Lot insisted, so at last they went home with him. Lot prepared a feast for them, complete with fresh bread made without yeast, and they ate.
speaker: Narrator

text: But before they retired for the night, all the men of Sodom, young and old, came from all over the city and surrounded the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shouted to Lot, “Where are the men who came to spend the night with you? Bring them out to us so we can have sex with them!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Lot stepped outside to talk to them, shutting the door behind him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Please, my brothers,” he begged, “don’t do such a wicked thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, I have two virgin daughters. Let me bring them out to you, and you can do with them as you wish. But please, leave these men alone, for they are my guests and are under my protection.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Stand back!” they shouted. “This fellow came to town as an outsider, and now he’s acting like our judge! We’ll treat you far worse than those other men!” And they lunged toward Lot to break down the door.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the two angels reached out, pulled Lot into the house, and bolted the door.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they blinded all the men, young and old, who were at the door of the house, so they gave up trying to get inside.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the angels questioned Lot. “Do you have any other relatives here in the city?” they asked. “Get them out of this place—your sons-in-law, sons, daughters, or anyone else.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we are about to destroy this city completely. The outcry against this place is so great it has reached the Lord, and he has sent us to destroy it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Lot rushed out to tell his daughters’ fiancés, “Quick, get out of the city! The Lord is about to destroy it.” But the young men thought he was only joking.
speaker: Narrator

text: At dawn the next morning the angels became insistent. “Hurry,” they said to Lot. “Take your wife and your two daughters who are here. Get out right now, or you will be swept away in the destruction of the city!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Lot still hesitated, the angels seized his hand and the hands of his wife and two daughters and rushed them to safety outside the city, for the Lord was merciful.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they were safely out of the city, one of the angels ordered, “Run for your lives! And don’t look back or stop anywhere in the valley! Escape to the mountains, or you will be swept away!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Oh no, my lord!” Lot begged.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You have been so gracious to me and saved my life, and you have shown such great kindness. But I cannot go to the mountains. Disaster would catch up to me there, and I would soon die.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, there is a small village nearby. Please let me go there instead; don’t you see how small it is? Then my life will be saved.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “All right,” the angel said, “I will grant your request. I will not destroy the little village.
speaker: Narrator

text: But hurry! Escape to it, for I can do nothing until you arrive there.” (This explains why that village was known as Zoar, which means “little place.”)
speaker: Narrator

text: Lot reached the village just as the sun was rising over the horizon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord rained down fire and burning sulfur from the sky on Sodom and Gomorrah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He utterly destroyed them, along with the other cities and villages of the plain, wiping out all the people and every bit of vegetation.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Lot’s wife looked back as she was following behind him, and she turned into a pillar of salt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham got up early that morning and hurried out to the place where he had stood in the Lord’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: He looked out across the plain toward Sodom and Gomorrah and watched as columns of smoke rose from the cities like smoke from a furnace.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God had listened to Abraham’s request and kept Lot safe, removing him from the disaster that engulfed the cities on the plain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward Lot left Zoar because he was afraid of the people there, and he went to live in a cave in the mountains with his two daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day the older daughter said to her sister, “There are no men left anywhere in this entire area, so we can’t get married like everyone else. And our father will soon be too old to have children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come, let’s get him drunk with wine, and then we will have sex with him. That way we will preserve our family line through our father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So that night they got him drunk with wine, and the older daughter went in and had intercourse with her father. He was unaware of her lying down or getting up again.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next morning the older daughter said to her younger sister, “I had sex with our father last night. Let’s get him drunk with wine again tonight, and you go in and have sex with him. That way we will preserve our family line through our father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So that night they got him drunk with wine again, and the younger daughter went in and had intercourse with him. As before, he was unaware of her lying down or getting up again.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result, both of Lot’s daughters became pregnant by their own father.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the older daughter gave birth to a son, she named him Moab. He became the ancestor of the nation now known as the Moabites.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the younger daughter gave birth to a son, she named him Ben-ammi. He became the ancestor of the nation now known as the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham moved south to the Negev and lived for a while between Kadesh and Shur, and then he moved on to Gerar. While living there as a foreigner,
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham introduced his wife, Sarah, by saying, “She is my sister.” So King Abimelech of Gerar sent for Sarah and had her brought to him at his palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: But that night God came to Abimelech in a dream and told him, “You are a dead man, for that woman you have taken is already married!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abimelech had not slept with her yet, so he said, “Lord, will you destroy an innocent nation?
speaker: Narrator

text: Didn’t Abraham tell me, ‘She is my sister’? And she herself said, ‘Yes, he is my brother.’ I acted in complete innocence! My hands are clean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the dream God responded, “Yes, I know you are innocent. That’s why I kept you from sinning against me, and why I did not let you touch her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now return the woman to her husband, and he will pray for you, for he is a prophet. Then you will live. But if you don’t return her to him, you can be sure that you and all your people will die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech got up early the next morning and quickly called all his servants together. When he told them what had happened, his men were terrified.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelech called for Abraham. “What have you done to us?” he demanded. “What crime have I committed that deserves treatment like this, making me and my kingdom guilty of this great sin? No one should ever do what you have done!
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever possessed you to do such a thing?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham replied, “I thought, ‘This is a godless place. They will want my wife and will kill me to get her.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And she really is my sister, for we both have the same father, but different mothers. And I married her.
speaker: Narrator

text: When God called me to leave my father’s home and to travel from place to place, I told her, ‘Do me a favor. Wherever we go, tell the people that I am your brother.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelech took some of his sheep and goats, cattle, and male and female servants, and he presented them to Abraham. He also returned his wife, Sarah, to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelech said, “Look over my land and choose any place where you would like to live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to Sarah, “Look, I am giving your ‘brother’ 1,000 pieces of silver in the presence of all these witnesses. This is to compensate you for any wrong I may have done to you. This will settle any claim against me, and your reputation is cleared.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham prayed to God, and God healed Abimelech, his wife, and his female servants, so they could have children.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord had caused all the women to be infertile because of what happened with Abraham’s wife, Sarah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord kept his word and did for Sarah exactly what he had promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: She became pregnant, and she gave birth to a son for Abraham in his old age. This happened at just the time God had said it would.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abraham named their son Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eight days after Isaac was born, Abraham circumcised him as God had commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham was 100 years old when Isaac was born.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Sarah declared, “God has brought me laughter. All who hear about this will laugh with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who would have said to Abraham that Sarah would nurse a baby? Yet I have given Abraham a son in his old age!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Isaac grew up and was about to be weaned, Abraham prepared a huge feast to celebrate the occasion.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Sarah saw Ishmael—the son of Abraham and her Egyptian servant Hagar—making fun of her son, Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: So she turned to Abraham and demanded, “Get rid of that slave woman and her son. He is not going to share the inheritance with my son, Isaac. I won’t have it!”
speaker: Narrator

text: This upset Abraham very much because Ishmael was his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God told Abraham, “Do not be upset over the boy and your servant. Do whatever Sarah tells you, for Isaac is the son through whom your descendants will be counted.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will also make a nation of the descendants of Hagar’s son because he is your son, too.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham got up early the next morning, prepared food and a container of water, and strapped them on Hagar’s shoulders. Then he sent her away with their son, and she wandered aimlessly in the wilderness of Beersheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the water was gone, she put the boy in the shade of a bush.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she went and sat down by herself about a hundred yards away. “I don’t want to watch the boy die,” she said, as she burst into tears.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God heard the boy crying, and the angel of God called to Hagar from heaven, “Hagar, what’s wrong? Do not be afraid! God has heard the boy crying as he lies there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go to him and comfort him, for I will make a great nation from his descendants.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God opened Hagar’s eyes, and she saw a well full of water. She quickly filled her water container and gave the boy a drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God was with the boy as he grew up in the wilderness. He became a skillful archer,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he settled in the wilderness of Paran. His mother arranged for him to marry a woman from the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: About this time, Abimelech came with Phicol, his army commander, to visit Abraham. “God is obviously with you, helping you in everything you do,” Abimelech said.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Swear to me in God’s name that you will never deceive me, my children, or any of my descendants. I have been loyal to you, so now swear that you will be loyal to me and to this country where you are living as a foreigner.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham replied, “Yes, I swear to it!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham complained to Abimelech about a well that Abimelech’s servants had taken by force from Abraham’s servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the first I’ve heard of it,” Abimelech answered. “I have no idea who is responsible. You have never complained about this before.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham then gave some of his sheep, goats, and cattle to Abimelech, and they made a treaty.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abraham also took seven additional female lambs and set them off by themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech asked, “Why have you set these seven apart from the others?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham replied, “Please accept these seven lambs to show your agreement that I dug this well.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he named the place Beersheba (which means “well of the oath”), because that was where they had sworn the oath.
speaker: Narrator

text: After making their covenant at Beersheba, Abimelech left with Phicol, the commander of his army, and they returned home to the land of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham planted a tamarisk tree at Beersheba, and there he worshiped the Lord, the Eternal God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abraham lived as a foreigner in Philistine country for a long time.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Some time later, God tested Abraham’s faith. “Abraham!” God called.
“Yes,” he replied. “Here I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take your son, your only son—yes, Isaac, whom you love so much—and go to the land of Moriah. Go and sacrifice him as a burnt offering on one of the mountains, which I will show you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The next morning Abraham got up early. He saddled his donkey and took two of his servants with him, along with his son, Isaac. Then he chopped wood for a fire for a burnt offering and set out for the place God had told him about.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the third day of their journey, Abraham looked up and saw the place in the distance.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Stay here with the donkey,” Abraham told the servants. “The boy and I will travel a little farther. We will worship there, and then we will come right back.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham placed the wood for the burnt offering on Isaac’s shoulders, while he himself carried the fire and the knife. As the two of them walked on together,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Isaac turned to Abraham and said, “Father?”
“Yes, my son?” Abraham replied.
“We have the fire and the wood,” the boy said, “but where is the sheep for the burnt offering?”
speaker: Narrator
