text: “God will provide a sheep for the burnt offering, my son,” Abraham answered. And they both walked on together.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they arrived at the place where God had told him to go, Abraham built an altar and arranged the wood on it. Then he tied his son, Isaac, and laid him on the altar on top of the wood.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abraham picked up the knife to kill his son as a sacrifice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At that moment the angel of the Lord called to him from heaven, “Abraham! Abraham!”
“Yes,” Abraham replied. “Here I am!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t lay a hand on the boy!” the angel said. “Do not hurt him in any way, for now I know that you truly fear God. You have not withheld from me even your son, your only son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham looked up and saw a ram caught by its horns in a thicket. So he took the ram and sacrificed it as a burnt offering in place of his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham named the place Yahweh-Yireh (which means “the Lord will provide”). To this day, people still use that name as a proverb: “On the mountain of the Lord it will be provided.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of the Lord called again to Abraham from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord says: Because you have obeyed me and have not withheld even your son, your only son, I swear by my own name that
speaker: Narrator

text: I will certainly bless you. I will multiply your descendants beyond number, like the stars in the sky and the sand on the seashore. Your descendants will conquer the cities of their enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: And through your descendants all the nations of the earth will be blessed—all because you have obeyed me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they returned to the servants and traveled back to Beersheba, where Abraham continued to live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Soon after this, Abraham heard that Milcah, his brother Nahor’s wife, had borne Nahor eight sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: The oldest was named Uz, the next oldest was Buz, followed by Kemuel (the ancestor of the Arameans),
speaker: Narrator

text: Kesed, Hazo, Pildash, Jidlaph, and Bethuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Bethuel became the father of Rebekah.) In addition to these eight sons from Milcah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Nahor had four other children from his concubine Reumah. Their names were Tebah, Gaham, Tahash, and Maacah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Sarah was 127 years old,
speaker: Narrator

text: she died at Kiriath-arba (now called Hebron) in the land of Canaan. There Abraham mourned and wept for her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, leaving her body, he said to the Hittite elders,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Here I am, a stranger and a foreigner among you. Please sell me a piece of land so I can give my wife a proper burial.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Hittites replied to Abraham,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Listen, my lord, you are an honored prince among us. Choose the finest of our tombs and bury her there. No one here will refuse to help you in this way.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham bowed low before the Hittites
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “Since you are willing to help me in this way, be so kind as to ask Ephron son of Zohar
speaker: Narrator

text: to let me buy his cave at Machpelah, down at the end of his field. I will pay the full price in the presence of witnesses, so I will have a permanent burial place for my family.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ephron was sitting there among the others, and he answered Abraham as the others listened, speaking publicly before all the Hittite elders of the town.
speaker: Narrator

text: “No, my lord,” he said to Abraham, “please listen to me. I will give you the field and the cave. Here in the presence of my people, I give it to you. Go and bury your dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham again bowed low before the citizens of the land,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he replied to Ephron as everyone listened. “No, listen to me. I will buy it from you. Let me pay the full price for the field so I can bury my dead there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ephron answered Abraham,
speaker: Narrator

text: “My lord, please listen to me. The land is worth 400 pieces of silver, but what is that between friends? Go ahead and bury your dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham agreed to Ephron’s price and paid the amount he had suggested—400 pieces of silver, weighed according to the market standard. The Hittite elders witnessed the transaction.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham bought the plot of land belonging to Ephron at Machpelah, near Mamre. This included the field itself, the cave that was in it, and all the surrounding trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was transferred to Abraham as his permanent possession in the presence of the Hittite elders at the city gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham buried his wife, Sarah, there in Canaan, in the cave of Machpelah, near Mamre (also called Hebron).
speaker: Narrator

text: So the field and the cave were transferred from the Hittites to Abraham for use as a permanent burial place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham was now a very old man, and the Lord had blessed him in every way.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Abraham said to his oldest servant, the man in charge of his household, “Take an oath by putting your hand under my thigh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Swear by the Lord, the God of heaven and earth, that you will not allow my son to marry one of these local Canaanite women.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go instead to my homeland, to my relatives, and find a wife there for my son Isaac.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The servant asked, “But what if I can’t find a young woman who is willing to travel so far from home? Should I then take Isaac there to live among your relatives in the land you came from?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “No!” Abraham responded. “Be careful never to take my son there.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord, the God of heaven, who took me from my father’s house and my native land, solemnly promised to give this land to my descendants. He will send his angel ahead of you, and he will see to it that you find a wife there for my son.
speaker: Narrator

text: If she is unwilling to come back with you, then you are free from this oath of mine. But under no circumstances are you to take my son there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the servant took an oath by putting his hand under the thigh of his master, Abraham. He swore to follow Abraham’s instructions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he loaded ten of Abraham’s camels with all kinds of expensive gifts from his master, and he traveled to distant Aram-naharaim. There he went to the town where Abraham’s brother Nahor had settled.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the camels kneel beside a well just outside the town. It was evening, and the women were coming out to draw water.
speaker: Narrator

text: “O Lord, God of my master, Abraham,” he prayed. “Please give me success today, and show unfailing love to my master, Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I am standing here beside this spring, and the young women of the town are coming out to draw water.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is my request. I will ask one of them, ‘Please give me a drink from your jug.’ If she says, ‘Yes, have a drink, and I will water your camels, too!’—let her be the one you have selected as Isaac’s wife. This is how I will know that you have shown unfailing love to my master.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Before he had finished praying, he saw a young woman named Rebekah coming out with her water jug on her shoulder. She was the daughter of Bethuel, who was the son of Abraham’s brother Nahor and his wife, Milcah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rebekah was very beautiful and old enough to be married, but she was still a virgin. She went down to the spring, filled her jug, and came up again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Running over to her, the servant said, “Please give me a little drink of water from your jug.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yes, my lord,” she answered, “have a drink.” And she quickly lowered her jug from her shoulder and gave him a drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she had given him a drink, she said, “I’ll draw water for your camels, too, until they have had enough to drink.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she quickly emptied her jug into the watering trough and ran back to the well to draw water for all his camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: The servant watched her in silence, wondering whether or not the Lord had given him success in his mission.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then at last, when the camels had finished drinking, he took out a gold ring for her nose and two large gold bracelets for her wrists.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whose daughter are you?” he asked. “And please tell me, would your father have any room to put us up for the night?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am the daughter of Bethuel,” she replied. “My grandparents are Nahor and Milcah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, we have plenty of straw and feed for the camels, and we have room for guests.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man bowed low and worshiped the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Praise the Lord, the God of my master, Abraham,” he said. “The Lord has shown unfailing love and faithfulness to my master, for he has led me straight to my master’s relatives.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The young woman ran home to tell her family everything that had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Rebekah had a brother named Laban, who ran out to meet the man at the spring.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had seen the nose-ring and the bracelets on his sister’s wrists, and had heard Rebekah tell what the man had said. So he rushed out to the spring, where the man was still standing beside his camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said to him, “Come and stay with us, you who are blessed by the Lord! Why are you standing here outside the town when I have a room all ready for you and a place prepared for the camels?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the man went home with Laban, and Laban unloaded the camels, gave him straw for their bedding, fed them, and provided water for the man and the camel drivers to wash their feet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then food was served. But Abraham’s servant said, “I don’t want to eat until I have told you why I have come.”
“All right,” Laban said, “tell us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am Abraham’s servant,” he explained.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And the Lord has greatly blessed my master; he has become a wealthy man. The Lord has given him flocks of sheep and goats, herds of cattle, a fortune in silver and gold, and many male and female servants and camels and donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When Sarah, my master’s wife, was very old, she gave birth to my master’s son, and my master has given him everything he owns.
speaker: Narrator

text: And my master made me take an oath. He said, ‘Do not allow my son to marry one of these local Canaanite women.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go instead to my father’s house, to my relatives, and find a wife there for my son.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But I said to my master, ‘What if I can’t find a young woman who is willing to go back with me?’
speaker: Narrator

text: He responded, ‘The Lord, in whose presence I have lived, will send his angel with you and will make your mission successful. Yes, you must find a wife for my son from among my relatives, from my father’s family.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will have fulfilled your obligation. But if you go to my relatives and they refuse to let her go with you, you will be free from my oath.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So today when I came to the spring, I prayed this prayer: ‘O Lord, God of my master, Abraham, please give me success on this mission.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I am standing here beside this spring. This is my request. When a young woman comes to draw water, I will say to her, “Please give me a little drink of water from your jug.”
speaker: Narrator

text: If she says, “Yes, have a drink, and I will draw water for your camels, too,” let her be the one you have selected to be the wife of my master’s son.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Before I had finished praying in my heart, I saw Rebekah coming out with her water jug on her shoulder. She went down to the spring and drew water. So I said to her, ‘Please give me a drink.’
speaker: Narrator

text: She quickly lowered her jug from her shoulder and said, ‘Yes, have a drink, and I will water your camels, too!’ So I drank, and then she watered the camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then I asked, ‘Whose daughter are you?’ She replied, ‘I am the daughter of Bethuel, and my grandparents are Nahor and Milcah.’ So I put the ring on her nose, and the bracelets on her wrists.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then I bowed low and worshiped the Lord. I praised the Lord, the God of my master, Abraham, because he had led me straight to my master’s niece to be his son’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: So tell me—will you or won’t you show unfailing love and faithfulness to my master? Please tell me yes or no, and then I’ll know what to do next.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Laban and Bethuel replied, “The Lord has obviously brought you here, so there is nothing we can say.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here is Rebekah; take her and go. Yes, let her be the wife of your master’s son, as the Lord has directed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abraham’s servant heard their answer, he bowed down to the ground and worshiped the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought out silver and gold jewelry and clothing and presented them to Rebekah. He also gave expensive presents to her brother and mother.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they ate their meal, and the servant and the men with him stayed there overnight.
But early the next morning, Abraham’s servant said, “Send me back to my master.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “But we want Rebekah to stay with us at least ten days,” her brother and mother said. “Then she can go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said, “Don’t delay me. The Lord has made my mission successful; now send me back so I can return to my master.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Well,” they said, “we’ll call Rebekah and ask her what she thinks.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So they called Rebekah. “Are you willing to go with this man?” they asked her.
And she replied, “Yes, I will go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they said good-bye to Rebekah and sent her away with Abraham’s servant and his men. The woman who had been Rebekah’s childhood nurse went along with her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They gave her this blessing as she parted: 
“Our sister, may you become
    the mother of many millions!
May your descendants be strong
    and conquer the cities of their enemies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rebekah and her servant girls mounted the camels and followed the man. So Abraham’s servant took Rebekah and went on his way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Isaac, whose home was in the Negev, had returned from Beer-lahai-roi.
speaker: Narrator

text: One evening as he was walking and meditating in the fields, he looked up and saw the camels coming.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Rebekah looked up and saw Isaac, she quickly dismounted from her camel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who is that man walking through the fields to meet us?” she asked the servant.
And he replied, “It is my master.” So Rebekah covered her face with her veil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the servant told Isaac everything he had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Isaac brought Rebekah into his mother Sarah’s tent, and she became his wife. He loved her deeply, and she was a special comfort to him after the death of his mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham married another wife, whose name was Keturah.
speaker: Narrator

text: She gave birth to Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jokshan was the father of Sheba and Dedan. Dedan’s descendants were the Asshurites, Letushites, and Leummites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Midian’s sons were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah. These were all descendants of Abraham through Keturah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham gave everything he owned to his son Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: But before he died, he gave gifts to the sons of his concubines and sent them off to a land in the east, away from Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham lived for 175 years,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he died at a ripe old age, having lived a long and satisfying life. He breathed his last and joined his ancestors in death.
speaker: Narrator

text: His sons Isaac and Ishmael buried him in the cave of Machpelah, near Mamre, in the field of Ephron son of Zohar the Hittite.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the field Abraham had purchased from the Hittites and where he had buried his wife Sarah.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Abraham’s death, God blessed his son Isaac, who settled near Beer-lahai-roi in the Negev.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the account of the family of Ishmael, the son of Abraham through Hagar, Sarah’s Egyptian servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here is a list, by their names and clans, of Ishmael’s descendants: The oldest was Nebaioth, followed by Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,
speaker: Narrator

text: Mishma, Dumah, Massa,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These twelve sons of Ishmael became the founders of twelve tribes named after them, listed according to the places they settled and camped.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ishmael lived for 137 years. Then he breathed his last and joined his ancestors in death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ishmael’s descendants occupied the region from Havilah to Shur, which is east of Egypt in the direction of Asshur. There they lived in open hostility toward all their relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the account of the family of Isaac, the son of Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Isaac was forty years old, he married Rebekah, the daughter of Bethuel the Aramean from Paddan-aram and the sister of Laban the Aramean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac pleaded with the Lord on behalf of his wife, because she was unable to have children. The Lord answered Isaac’s prayer, and Rebekah became pregnant with twins.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the two children struggled with each other in her womb. So she went to ask the Lord about it. “Why is this happening to me?” she asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord told her, “The sons in your womb will become two nations. From the very beginning, the two nations will be rivals. One nation will be stronger than the other; and your older son will serve your younger son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the time came to give birth, Rebekah discovered that she did indeed have twins!
speaker: Narrator

text: The first one was very red at birth and covered with thick hair like a fur coat. So they named him Esau.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the other twin was born with his hand grasping Esau’s heel. So they named him Jacob. Isaac was sixty years old when the twins were born.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the boys grew up, Esau became a skillful hunter. He was an outdoorsman, but Jacob had a quiet temperament, preferring to stay at home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac loved Esau because he enjoyed eating the wild game Esau brought home, but Rebekah loved Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day when Jacob was cooking some stew, Esau arrived home from the wilderness exhausted and hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau said to Jacob, “I’m starved! Give me some of that red stew!” (This is how Esau got his other name, Edom, which means “red.”)
speaker: Narrator

text: “All right,” Jacob replied, “but trade me your rights as the firstborn son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look, I’m dying of starvation!” said Esau. “What good is my birthright to me now?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob said, “First you must swear that your birthright is mine.” So Esau swore an oath, thereby selling all his rights as the firstborn to his brother, Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob gave Esau some bread and lentil stew. Esau ate the meal, then got up and left. He showed contempt for his rights as the firstborn.
speaker: Narrator

text: A severe famine now struck the land, as had happened before in Abraham’s time. So Isaac moved to Gerar, where Abimelech, king of the Philistines, lived.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord appeared to Isaac and said, “Do not go down to Egypt, but do as I tell you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Live here as a foreigner in this land, and I will be with you and bless you. I hereby confirm that I will give all these lands to you and your descendants, just as I solemnly promised Abraham, your father.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will cause your descendants to become as numerous as the stars of the sky, and I will give them all these lands. And through your descendants all the nations of the earth will be blessed.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will do this because Abraham listened to me and obeyed all my requirements, commands, decrees, and instructions.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac stayed in Gerar.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men who lived there asked Isaac about his wife, Rebekah, he said, “She is my sister.” He was afraid to say, “She is my wife.” He thought, “They will kill me to get her, because she is so beautiful.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But some time later, Abimelech, king of the Philistines, looked out his window and saw Isaac caressing Rebekah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Immediately, Abimelech called for Isaac and exclaimed, “She is obviously your wife! Why did you say, ‘She is my sister’?”
“Because I was afraid someone would kill me to get her from me,” Isaac replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: “How could you do this to us?” Abimelech exclaimed. “One of my people might easily have taken your wife and slept with her, and you would have made us guilty of great sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelech issued a public proclamation: “Anyone who touches this man or his wife will be put to death!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Isaac planted his crops that year, he harvested a hundred times more grain than he planted, for the Lord blessed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He became a very rich man, and his wealth continued to grow.
speaker: Narrator

text: He acquired so many flocks of sheep and goats, herds of cattle, and servants that the Philistines became jealous of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Philistines filled up all of Isaac’s wells with dirt. These were the wells that had been dug by the servants of his father, Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, Abimelech ordered Isaac to leave the country. “Go somewhere else,” he said, “for you have become too powerful for us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac moved away to the Gerar Valley, where he set up their tents and settled down.
speaker: Narrator

text: He reopened the wells his father had dug, which the Philistines had filled in after Abraham’s death. Isaac also restored the names Abraham had given them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac’s servants also dug in the Gerar Valley and discovered a well of fresh water.
speaker: Narrator

text: But then the shepherds from Gerar came and claimed the spring. “This is our water,” they said, and they argued over it with Isaac’s herdsmen. So Isaac named the well Esek (which means “argument”).
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac’s men then dug another well, but again there was a dispute over it. So Isaac named it Sitnah (which means “hostility”).
speaker: Narrator

text: Abandoning that one, Isaac moved on and dug another well. This time there was no dispute over it, so Isaac named the place Rehoboth (which means “open space”), for he said, “At last the Lord has created enough space for us to prosper in this land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: From there Isaac moved to Beersheba,
speaker: Narrator

text: where the Lord appeared to him on the night of his arrival. “I am the God of your father, Abraham,” he said. “Do not be afraid, for I am with you and will bless you. I will multiply your descendants, and they will become a great nation. I will do this because of my promise to Abraham, my servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaac built an altar there and worshiped the Lord. He set up his camp at that place, and his servants dug another well.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day King Abimelech came from Gerar with his adviser, Ahuzzath, and also Phicol, his army commander.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why have you come here?” Isaac asked. “You obviously hate me, since you kicked me off your land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They replied, “We can plainly see that the Lord is with you. So we want to enter into a sworn treaty with you. Let’s make a covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Swear that you will not harm us, just as we have never troubled you. We have always treated you well, and we sent you away from us in peace. And now look how the Lord has blessed you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac prepared a covenant feast to celebrate the treaty, and they ate and drank together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Early the next morning, they each took a solemn oath not to interfere with each other. Then Isaac sent them home again, and they left him in peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: That very day Isaac’s servants came and told him about a new well they had dug. “We’ve found water!” they exclaimed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac named the well Shibah (which means “oath”). And to this day the town that grew up there is called Beersheba (which means “well of the oath”).
speaker: Narrator

text: At the age of forty, Esau married two Hittite wives: Judith, the daughter of Beeri, and Basemath, the daughter of Elon.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Esau’s wives made life miserable for Isaac and Rebekah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One day when Isaac was old and turning blind, he called for Esau, his older son, and said, “My son.”
“Yes, Father?” Esau replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am an old man now,” Isaac said, “and I don’t know when I may die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take your bow and a quiver full of arrows, and go out into the open country to hunt some wild game for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Prepare my favorite dish, and bring it here for me to eat. Then I will pronounce the blessing that belongs to you, my firstborn son, before I die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Rebekah overheard what Isaac had said to his son Esau. So when Esau left to hunt for the wild game,
speaker: Narrator

text: she said to her son Jacob, “Listen. I overheard your father say to Esau,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Bring me some wild game and prepare me a delicious meal. Then I will bless you in the Lord’s presence before I die.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, my son, listen to me. Do exactly as I tell you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go out to the flocks, and bring me two fine young goats. I’ll use them to prepare your father’s favorite dish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then take the food to your father so he can eat it and bless you before he dies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “But look,” Jacob replied to Rebekah, “my brother, Esau, is a hairy man, and my skin is smooth.
speaker: Narrator

text: What if my father touches me? He’ll see that I’m trying to trick him, and then he’ll curse me instead of blessing me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But his mother replied, “Then let the curse fall on me, my son! Just do what I tell you. Go out and get the goats for me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob went out and got the young goats for his mother. Rebekah took them and prepared a delicious meal, just the way Isaac liked it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she took Esau’s favorite clothes, which were there in the house, and gave them to her younger son, Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: She covered his arms and the smooth part of his neck with the skin of the young goats.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she gave Jacob the delicious meal, including freshly baked bread.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Jacob took the food to his father. “My father?” he said.
“Yes, my son,” Isaac answered. “Who are you—Esau or Jacob?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob replied, “It’s Esau, your firstborn son. I’ve done as you told me. Here is the wild game. Now sit up and eat it so you can give me your blessing.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Isaac asked, “How did you find it so quickly, my son?”
“The Lord your God put it in my path!” Jacob replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaac said to Jacob, “Come closer so I can touch you and make sure that you really are Esau.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob went closer to his father, and Isaac touched him. “The voice is Jacob’s, but the hands are Esau’s,” Isaac said.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he did not recognize Jacob, because Jacob’s hands felt hairy just like Esau’s. So Isaac prepared to bless Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But are you really my son Esau?” he asked.
“Yes, I am,” Jacob replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaac said, “Now, my son, bring me the wild game. Let me eat it, and then I will give you my blessing.” So Jacob took the food to his father, and Isaac ate it. He also drank the wine that Jacob served him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaac said to Jacob, “Please come a little closer and kiss me, my son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob went over and kissed him. And when Isaac caught the smell of his clothes, he was finally convinced, and he blessed his son. He said, “Ah! The smell of my son is like the smell of the outdoors, which the Lord has blessed!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“From the dew of heaven
    and the richness of the earth,
may God always give you abundant harvests of grain
    and bountiful new wine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May many nations become your servants,
    and may they bow down to you.
May you be the master over your brothers,
    and may your mother’s sons bow down to you.
All who curse you will be cursed,
    and all who bless you will be blessed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as Isaac had finished blessing Jacob, and almost before Jacob had left his father, Esau returned from his hunt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau prepared a delicious meal and brought it to his father. Then he said, “Sit up, my father, and eat my wild game so you can give me your blessing.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But Isaac asked him, “Who are you?”
Esau replied, “It’s your son, your firstborn son, Esau.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac began to tremble uncontrollably and said, “Then who just served me wild game? I have already eaten it, and I blessed him just before you came. And yes, that blessing must stand!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Esau heard his father’s words, he let out a loud and bitter cry. “Oh my father, what about me? Bless me, too!” he begged.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Isaac said, “Your brother was here, and he tricked me. He has taken away your blessing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau exclaimed, “No wonder his name is Jacob, for now he has cheated me twice. First he took my rights as the firstborn, and now he has stolen my blessing. Oh, haven’t you saved even one blessing for me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac said to Esau, “I have made Jacob your master and have declared that all his brothers will be his servants. I have guaranteed him an abundance of grain and wine—what is left for me to give you, my son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau pleaded, “But do you have only one blessing? Oh my father, bless me, too!” Then Esau broke down and wept.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Finally, his father, Isaac, said to him, 
“You will live away from the richness of the earth,
    and away from the dew of the heaven above.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will live by your sword,
    and you will serve your brother.
But when you decide to break free,
    you will shake his yoke from your neck.”
speaker: Narrator

text: From that time on, Esau hated Jacob because their father had given Jacob the blessing. And Esau began to scheme: “I will soon be mourning my father’s death. Then I will kill my brother, Jacob.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Rebekah heard about Esau’s plans. So she sent for Jacob and told him, “Listen, Esau is consoling himself by plotting to kill you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So listen carefully, my son. Get ready and flee to my brother, Laban, in Haran.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stay there with him until your brother cools off.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he calms down and forgets what you have done to him, I will send for you to come back. Why should I lose both of you in one day?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rebekah said to Isaac, “I’m sick and tired of these local Hittite women! I would rather die than see Jacob marry one of them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac called for Jacob, blessed him, and said, “You must not marry any of these Canaanite women.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, go at once to Paddan-aram, to the house of your grandfather Bethuel, and marry one of your uncle Laban’s daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: May God Almighty bless you and give you many children. And may your descendants multiply and become many nations!
speaker: Narrator

text: May God pass on to you and your descendants the blessings he promised to Abraham. May you own this land where you are now living as a foreigner, for God gave this land to Abraham.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac sent Jacob away, and he went to Paddan-aram to stay with his uncle Laban, his mother’s brother, the son of Bethuel the Aramean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau knew that his father, Isaac, had blessed Jacob and sent him to Paddan-aram to find a wife, and that he had warned Jacob, “You must not marry a Canaanite woman.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He also knew that Jacob had obeyed his parents and gone to Paddan-aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was now very clear to Esau that his father did not like the local Canaanite women.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Esau visited his uncle Ishmael’s family and married one of Ishmael’s daughters, in addition to the wives he already had. His new wife’s name was Mahalath. She was the sister of Nebaioth and the daughter of Ishmael, Abraham’s son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Jacob left Beersheba and traveled toward Haran.
speaker: Narrator

text: At sundown he arrived at a good place to set up camp and stopped there for the night. Jacob found a stone to rest his head against and lay down to sleep.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he slept, he dreamed of a stairway that reached from the earth up to heaven. And he saw the angels of God going up and down the stairway.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the top of the stairway stood the Lord, and he said, “I am the Lord, the God of your grandfather Abraham, and the God of your father, Isaac. The ground you are lying on belongs to you. I am giving it to you and your descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your descendants will be as numerous as the dust of the earth! They will spread out in all directions—to the west and the east, to the north and the south. And all the families of the earth will be blessed through you and your descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: What’s more, I am with you, and I will protect you wherever you go. One day I will bring you back to this land. I will not leave you until I have finished giving you everything I have promised you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob awoke from his sleep and said, “Surely the Lord is in this place, and I wasn’t even aware of it!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he was also afraid and said, “What an awesome place this is! It is none other than the house of God, the very gateway to heaven!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The next morning Jacob got up very early. He took the stone he had rested his head against, and he set it upright as a memorial pillar. Then he poured olive oil over it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He named that place Bethel (which means “house of God”), although it was previously called Luz.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob made this vow: “If God will indeed be with me and protect me on this journey, and if he will provide me with food and clothing,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if I return safely to my father’s home, then the Lord will certainly be my God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this memorial pillar I have set up will become a place for worshiping God, and I will present to God a tenth of everything he gives me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob hurried on, finally arriving in the land of the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: He saw a well in the distance. Three flocks of sheep and goats lay in an open field beside it, waiting to be watered. But a heavy stone covered the mouth of the well.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was the custom there to wait for all the flocks to arrive before removing the stone and watering the animals. Afterward the stone would be placed back over the mouth of the well.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jacob went over to the shepherds and asked, “Where are you from, my friends?”
“We are from Haran,” they answered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do you know a man there named Laban, the grandson of Nahor?” he asked.
“Yes, we do,” they replied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Is he doing well?” Jacob asked.
“Yes, he’s well,” they answered. “Look, here comes his daughter Rachel with the flock now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob said, “Look, it’s still broad daylight—too early to round up the animals. Why don’t you water the sheep and goats so they can get back out to pasture?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “We can’t water the animals until all the flocks have arrived,” they replied. “Then the shepherds move the stone from the mouth of the well, and we water all the sheep and goats.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob was still talking with them when Rachel arrived with her father’s flock, for she was a shepherd.
speaker: Narrator

text: And because Rachel was his cousin—the daughter of Laban, his mother’s brother—and because the sheep and goats belonged to his uncle Laban, Jacob went over to the well and moved the stone from its mouth and watered his uncle’s flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob kissed Rachel, and he wept aloud.
speaker: Narrator

text: He explained to Rachel that he was her cousin on her father’s side—the son of her aunt Rebekah. So Rachel quickly ran and told her father, Laban.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as Laban heard that his nephew Jacob had arrived, he ran out to meet him. He embraced and kissed him and brought him home. When Jacob had told him his story,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Laban exclaimed, “You really are my own flesh and blood!”
After Jacob had stayed with Laban for about a month,
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said to him, “You shouldn’t work for me without pay just because we are relatives. Tell me how much your wages should be.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Laban had two daughters. The older daughter was named Leah, and the younger one was Rachel.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was no sparkle in Leah’s eyes, but Rachel had a beautiful figure and a lovely face.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since Jacob was in love with Rachel, he told her father, “I’ll work for you for seven years if you’ll give me Rachel, your younger daughter, as my wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Agreed!” Laban replied. “I’d rather give her to you than to anyone else. Stay and work with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob worked seven years to pay for Rachel. But his love for her was so strong that it seemed to him but a few days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, the time came for him to marry her. “I have fulfilled my agreement,” Jacob said to Laban. “Now give me my wife so I can sleep with her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Laban invited everyone in the neighborhood and prepared a wedding feast.
speaker: Narrator

text: But that night, when it was dark, Laban took Leah to Jacob, and he slept with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Laban had given Leah a servant, Zilpah, to be her maid.)
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Jacob woke up in the morning—it was Leah! “What have you done to me?” Jacob raged at Laban. “I worked seven years for Rachel! Why have you tricked me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “It’s not our custom here to marry off a younger daughter ahead of the firstborn,” Laban replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But wait until the bridal week is over; then we’ll give you Rachel, too—provided you promise to work another seven years for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob agreed to work seven more years. A week after Jacob had married Leah, Laban gave him Rachel, too.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Laban gave Rachel a servant, Bilhah, to be her maid.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob slept with Rachel, too, and he loved her much more than Leah. He then stayed and worked for Laban the additional seven years.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord saw that Leah was unloved, he enabled her to have children, but Rachel could not conceive.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Leah became pregnant and gave birth to a son. She named him Reuben, for she said, “The Lord has noticed my misery, and now my husband will love me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She soon became pregnant again and gave birth to another son. She named him Simeon, for she said, “The Lord heard that I was unloved and has given me another son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she became pregnant a third time and gave birth to another son. He was named Levi, for she said, “Surely this time my husband will feel affection for me, since I have given him three sons!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Once again Leah became pregnant and gave birth to another son. She named him Judah, for she said, “Now I will praise the Lord!” And then she stopped having children.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Rachel saw that she wasn’t having any children for Jacob, she became jealous of her sister. She pleaded with Jacob, “Give me children, or I’ll die!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob became furious with Rachel. “Am I God?” he asked. “He’s the one who has kept you from having children!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rachel told him, “Take my maid, Bilhah, and sleep with her. She will bear children for me, and through her I can have a family, too.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Rachel gave her servant, Bilhah, to Jacob as a wife, and he slept with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bilhah became pregnant and presented him with a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rachel named him Dan, for she said, “God has vindicated me! He has heard my request and given me a son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Bilhah became pregnant again and gave Jacob a second son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rachel named him Naphtali, for she said, “I have struggled hard with my sister, and I’m winning!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Leah realized that she wasn’t getting pregnant anymore, so she took her servant, Zilpah, and gave her to Jacob as a wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Soon Zilpah presented him with a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah named him Gad, for she said, “How fortunate I am!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Zilpah gave Jacob a second son.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Leah named him Asher, for she said, “What joy is mine! Now the other women will celebrate with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day during the wheat harvest, Reuben found some mandrakes growing in a field and brought them to his mother, Leah. Rachel begged Leah, “Please give me some of your son’s mandrakes.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But Leah angrily replied, “Wasn’t it enough that you stole my husband? Now will you steal my son’s mandrakes, too?”
Rachel answered, “I will let Jacob sleep with you tonight if you give me some of the mandrakes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So that evening, as Jacob was coming home from the fields, Leah went out to meet him. “You must come and sleep with me tonight!” she said. “I have paid for you with some mandrakes that my son found.” So that night he slept with Leah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God answered Leah’s prayers. She became pregnant again and gave birth to a fifth son for Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: She named him Issachar, for she said, “God has rewarded me for giving my servant to my husband as a wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Leah became pregnant again and gave birth to a sixth son for Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: She named him Zebulun, for she said, “God has given me a good reward. Now my husband will treat me with respect, for I have given him six sons.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Later she gave birth to a daughter and named her Dinah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God remembered Rachel’s plight and answered her prayers by enabling her to have children.
speaker: Narrator

text: She became pregnant and gave birth to a son. “God has removed my disgrace,” she said.
speaker: Narrator

text: And she named him Joseph, for she said, “May the Lord add yet another son to my family.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Soon after Rachel had given birth to Joseph, Jacob said to Laban, “Please release me so I can go home to my own country.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let me take my wives and children, for I have earned them by serving you, and let me be on my way. You certainly know how hard I have worked for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Please listen to me,” Laban replied. “I have become wealthy, for the Lord has blessed me because of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell me how much I owe you. Whatever it is, I’ll pay it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob replied, “You know how hard I’ve worked for you, and how your flocks and herds have grown under my care.
speaker: Narrator

text: You had little indeed before I came, but your wealth has increased enormously. The Lord has blessed you through everything I’ve done. But now, what about me? When can I start providing for my own family?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What wages do you want?” Laban asked again.
Jacob replied, “Don’t give me anything. Just do this one thing, and I’ll continue to tend and watch over your flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let me inspect your flocks today and remove all the sheep and goats that are speckled or spotted, along with all the black sheep. Give these to me as my wages.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the future, when you check on the animals you have given me as my wages, you’ll see that I have been honest. If you find in my flock any goats without speckles or spots, or any sheep that are not black, you will know that I have stolen them from you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “All right,” Laban replied. “It will be as you say.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But that very day Laban went out and removed the male goats that were streaked and spotted, all the female goats that were speckled and spotted or had white patches, and all the black sheep. He placed them in the care of his own sons,
speaker: Narrator

text: who took them a three-days’ journey from where Jacob was. Meanwhile, Jacob stayed and cared for the rest of Laban’s flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob took some fresh branches from poplar, almond, and plane trees and peeled off strips of bark, making white streaks on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he placed these peeled branches in the watering troughs where the flocks came to drink, for that was where they mated.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they mated in front of the white-streaked branches, they gave birth to young that were streaked, speckled, and spotted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob separated those lambs from Laban’s flock. And at mating time he turned the flock to face Laban’s animals that were streaked or black. This is how he built his own flock instead of increasing Laban’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the stronger females were ready to mate, Jacob would place the peeled branches in the watering troughs in front of them. Then they would mate in front of the branches.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he didn’t do this with the weaker ones, so the weaker lambs belonged to Laban, and the stronger ones were Jacob’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result, Jacob became very wealthy, with large flocks of sheep and goats, female and male servants, and many camels and donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob soon learned that Laban’s sons were grumbling about him. “Jacob has robbed our father of everything!” they said. “He has gained all his wealth at our father’s expense.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jacob began to notice a change in Laban’s attitude toward him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Jacob, “Return to the land of your father and grandfather and to your relatives there, and I will be with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob called Rachel and Leah out to the field where he was watching his flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “I have noticed that your father’s attitude toward me has changed. But the God of my father has been with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know how hard I have worked for your father,
speaker: Narrator

text: but he has cheated me, changing my wages ten times. But God has not allowed him to do me any harm.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if he said, ‘The speckled animals will be your wages,’ the whole flock began to produce speckled young. And when he changed his mind and said, ‘The striped animals will be your wages,’ then the whole flock produced striped young.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way, God has taken your father’s animals and given them to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “One time during the mating season, I had a dream and saw that the male goats mating with the females were streaked, speckled, and spotted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then in my dream, the angel of God said to me, ‘Jacob!’ And I replied, ‘Yes, here I am.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The angel said, ‘Look up, and you will see that only the streaked, speckled, and spotted males are mating with the females of your flock. For I have seen how Laban has treated you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the God who appeared to you at Bethel, the place where you anointed the pillar of stone and made your vow to me. Now get ready and leave this country and return to the land of your birth.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Rachel and Leah responded, “That’s fine with us! We won’t inherit any of our father’s wealth anyway.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has reduced our rights to those of foreign women. And after he sold us, he wasted the money you paid him for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the wealth God has given you from our father legally belongs to us and our children. So go ahead and do whatever God has told you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob put his wives and children on camels,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he drove all his livestock in front of him. He packed all the belongings he had acquired in Paddan-aram and set out for the land of Canaan, where his father, Isaac, lived.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the time they left, Laban was some distance away, shearing his sheep. Rachel stole her father’s household idols and took them with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob outwitted Laban the Aramean, for they set out secretly and never told Laban they were leaving.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob took all his possessions with him and crossed the Euphrates River, heading for the hill country of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three days later, Laban was told that Jacob had fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he gathered a group of his relatives and set out in hot pursuit. He caught up with Jacob seven days later in the hill country of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the previous night God had appeared to Laban the Aramean in a dream and told him, “I’m warning you—leave Jacob alone!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban caught up with Jacob as he was camped in the hill country of Gilead, and he set up his camp not far from Jacob’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: “What do you mean by deceiving me like this?” Laban demanded. “How dare you drag my daughters away like prisoners of war?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why did you slip away secretly? Why did you deceive me? And why didn’t you say you wanted to leave? I would have given you a farewell feast, with singing and music, accompanied by tambourines and harps.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why didn’t you let me kiss my daughters and grandchildren and tell them good-bye? You have acted very foolishly!
speaker: Narrator

text: I could destroy you, but the God of your father appeared to me last night and warned me, ‘Leave Jacob alone!’
speaker: Narrator

text: I can understand your feeling that you must go, and your intense longing for your father’s home. But why have you stolen my gods?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I rushed away because I was afraid,” Jacob answered. “I thought you would take your daughters from me by force.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for your gods, see if you can find them, and let the person who has taken them die! And if you find anything else that belongs to you, identify it before all these relatives of ours, and I will give it back!” But Jacob did not know that Rachel had stolen the household idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban went first into Jacob’s tent to search there, then into Leah’s, and then the tents of the two servant wives—but he found nothing. Finally, he went into Rachel’s tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Rachel had taken the household idols and hidden them in her camel saddle, and now she was sitting on them. When Laban had thoroughly searched her tent without finding them,
speaker: Narrator

text: she said to her father, “Please, sir, forgive me if I don’t get up for you. I’m having my monthly period.” So Laban continued his search, but he could not find the household idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob became very angry, and he challenged Laban. “What’s my crime?” he demanded. “What have I done wrong to make you chase after me as though I were a criminal?
speaker: Narrator

text: You have rummaged through everything I own. Now show me what you found that belongs to you! Set it out here in front of us, before our relatives, for all to see. Let them judge between us!
speaker: Narrator

text: “For twenty years I have been with you, caring for your flocks. In all that time your sheep and goats never miscarried. In all those years I never used a single ram of yours for food.
speaker: Narrator

text: If any were attacked and killed by wild animals, I never showed you the carcass and asked you to reduce the count of your flock. No, I took the loss myself! You made me pay for every stolen animal, whether it was taken in broad daylight or in the dark of night.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I worked for you through the scorching heat of the day and through cold and sleepless nights.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, for twenty years I slaved in your house! I worked for fourteen years earning your two daughters, and then six more years for your flock. And you changed my wages ten times!
speaker: Narrator

text: In fact, if the God of my father had not been on my side—the God of Abraham and the fearsome God of Isaac—you would have sent me away empty-handed. But God has seen your abuse and my hard work. That is why he appeared to you last night and rebuked you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Laban replied to Jacob, “These women are my daughters, these children are my grandchildren, and these flocks are my flocks—in fact, everything you see is mine. But what can I do now about my daughters and their children?
speaker: Narrator

text: So come, let’s make a covenant, you and I, and it will be a witness to our commitment.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob took a stone and set it up as a monument.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he told his family members, “Gather some stones.” So they gathered stones and piled them in a heap. Then Jacob and Laban sat down beside the pile of stones to eat a covenant meal.
speaker: Narrator

text: To commemorate the event, Laban called the place Jegar-sahadutha (which means “witness pile” in Aramaic), and Jacob called it Galeed (which means “witness pile” in Hebrew).
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Laban declared, “This pile of stones will stand as a witness to remind us of the covenant we have made today.” This explains why it was called Galeed—“Witness Pile.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But it was also called Mizpah (which means “watchtower”), for Laban said, “May the Lord keep watch between us to make sure that we keep this covenant when we are out of each other’s sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you mistreat my daughters or if you marry other wives, God will see it even if no one else does. He is a witness to this covenant between us.
speaker: Narrator

text: “See this pile of stones,” Laban continued, “and see this monument I have set between us.
speaker: Narrator

text: They stand between us as witnesses of our vows. I will never pass this pile of stones to harm you, and you must never pass these stones or this monument to harm me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I call on the God of our ancestors—the God of your grandfather Abraham and the God of my grandfather Nahor—to serve as a judge between us.”
So Jacob took an oath before the fearsome God of his father, Isaac, to respect the boundary line.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob offered a sacrifice to God there on the mountain and invited everyone to a covenant feast. After they had eaten, they spent the night on the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban got up early the next morning, and he kissed his grandchildren and his daughters and blessed them. Then he left and returned home.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Jacob started on his way again, angels of God came to meet him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob saw them, he exclaimed, “This is God’s camp!” So he named the place Mahanaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob sent messengers ahead to his brother, Esau, who was living in the region of Seir in the land of Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told them, “Give this message to my master Esau: ‘Humble greetings from your servant Jacob. Until now I have been living with Uncle Laban,
speaker: Narrator

text: and now I own cattle, donkeys, flocks of sheep and goats, and many servants, both men and women. I have sent these messengers to inform my lord of my coming, hoping that you will be friendly to me.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: After delivering the message, the messengers returned to Jacob and reported, “We met your brother, Esau, and he is already on his way to meet you—with an army of 400 men!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob was terrified at the news. He divided his household, along with the flocks and herds and camels, into two groups.
speaker: Narrator

text: He thought, “If Esau meets one group and attacks it, perhaps the other group can escape.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob prayed, “O God of my grandfather Abraham, and God of my father, Isaac—O Lord, you told me, ‘Return to your own land and to your relatives.’ And you promised me, ‘I will treat you kindly.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I am not worthy of all the unfailing love and faithfulness you have shown to me, your servant. When I left home and crossed the Jordan River, I owned nothing except a walking stick. Now my household fills two large camps!
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord, please rescue me from the hand of my brother, Esau. I am afraid that he is coming to attack me, along with my wives and children.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you promised me, ‘I will surely treat you kindly, and I will multiply your descendants until they become as numerous as the sands along the seashore—too many to count.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob stayed where he was for the night. Then he selected these gifts from his possessions to present to his brother, Esau:
speaker: Narrator

text: 200 female goats, 20 male goats, 200 ewes, 20 rams,
speaker: Narrator

text: 30 female camels with their young, 40 cows, 10 bulls, 20 female donkeys, and 10 male donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: He divided these animals into herds and assigned each to different servants. Then he told his servants, “Go ahead of me with the animals, but keep some distance between the herds.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave these instructions to the men leading the first group: “When my brother, Esau, meets you, he will ask, ‘Whose servants are you? Where are you going? Who owns these animals?’
speaker: Narrator

text: You must reply, ‘They belong to your servant Jacob, but they are a gift for his master Esau. Look, he is coming right behind us.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob gave the same instructions to the second and third herdsmen and to all who followed behind the herds: “You must say the same thing to Esau when you meet him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And be sure to say, ‘Look, your servant Jacob is right behind us.’”
Jacob thought, “I will try to appease him by sending gifts ahead of me. When I see him in person, perhaps he will be friendly to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the gifts were sent on ahead, while Jacob himself spent that night in the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: During the night Jacob got up and took his two wives, his two servant wives, and his eleven sons and crossed the Jabbok River with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: After taking them to the other side, he sent over all his possessions.
speaker: Narrator

text: This left Jacob all alone in the camp, and a man came and wrestled with him until the dawn began to break.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the man saw that he would not win the match, he touched Jacob’s hip and wrenched it out of its socket.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the man said, “Let me go, for the dawn is breaking!”
But Jacob said, “I will not let you go unless you bless me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What is your name?” the man asked.
He replied, “Jacob.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your name will no longer be Jacob,” the man told him. “From now on you will be called Israel, because you have fought with God and with men and have won.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Please tell me your name,” Jacob said.
“Why do you want to know my name?” the man replied. Then he blessed Jacob there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob named the place Peniel (which means “face of God”), for he said, “I have seen God face to face, yet my life has been spared.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The sun was rising as Jacob left Peniel, and he was limping because of the injury to his hip.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Even today the people of Israel don’t eat the tendon near the hip socket because of what happened that night when the man strained the tendon of Jacob’s hip.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob looked up and saw Esau coming with his 400 men. So he divided the children among Leah, Rachel, and his two servant wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put the servant wives and their children at the front, Leah and her children next, and Rachel and Joseph last.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob went on ahead. As he approached his brother, he bowed to the ground seven times before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Esau ran to meet him and embraced him, threw his arms around his neck, and kissed him. And they both wept.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Esau looked at the women and children and asked, “Who are these people with you?”
“These are the children God has graciously given to me, your servant,” Jacob replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the servant wives came forward with their children and bowed before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next came Leah with her children, and they bowed before him. Finally, Joseph and Rachel came forward and bowed before him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“And what were all the flocks and herds I met as I came?” Esau asked.
Jacob replied, “They are a gift, my lord, to ensure your friendship.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “My brother, I have plenty,” Esau answered. “Keep what you have for yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob insisted, “No, if I have found favor with you, please accept this gift from me. And what a relief to see your friendly smile. It is like seeing the face of God!
speaker: Narrator

text: Please take this gift I have brought you, for God has been very gracious to me. I have more than enough.” And because Jacob insisted, Esau finally accepted the gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Well,” Esau said, “let’s be going. I will lead the way.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob replied, “You can see, my lord, that some of the children are very young, and the flocks and herds have their young, too. If they are driven too hard, even for one day, all the animals could die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please, my lord, go ahead of your servant. We will follow slowly, at a pace that is comfortable for the livestock and the children. I will meet you at Seir.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“All right,” Esau said, “but at least let me assign some of my men to guide and protect you.”
Jacob responded, “That’s not necessary. It’s enough that you’ve received me warmly, my lord!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Esau turned around and started back to Seir that same day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob, on the other hand, traveled on to Succoth. There he built himself a house and made shelters for his livestock. That is why the place was named Succoth (which means “shelters”).
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, having traveled all the way from Paddan-aram, Jacob arrived safely at the town of Shechem, in the land of Canaan. There he set up camp outside the town.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob bought the plot of land where he camped from the family of Hamor, the father of Shechem, for 100 pieces of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there he built an altar and named it El-Elohe-Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Dinah, the daughter of Jacob and Leah, went to visit some of the young women who lived in the area.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the local prince, Shechem son of Hamor the Hivite, saw Dinah, he seized her and raped her.
speaker: Narrator

text: But then he fell in love with her, and he tried to win her affection with tender words.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to his father, Hamor, “Get me this young girl. I want to marry her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Soon Jacob heard that Shechem had defiled his daughter, Dinah. But since his sons were out in the fields herding his livestock, he said nothing until they returned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hamor, Shechem’s father, came to discuss the matter with Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Jacob’s sons had come in from the field as soon as they heard what had happened. They were shocked and furious that their sister had been raped. Shechem had done a disgraceful thing against Jacob’s family, something that should never be done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hamor tried to speak with Jacob and his sons. “My son Shechem is truly in love with your daughter,” he said. “Please let him marry her.
speaker: Narrator

text: In fact, let’s arrange other marriages, too. You give us your daughters for our sons, and we will give you our daughters for your sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you may live among us; the land is open to you! Settle here and trade with us. And feel free to buy property in the area.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Shechem himself spoke to Dinah’s father and brothers. “Please be kind to me, and let me marry her,” he begged. “I will give you whatever you ask.
speaker: Narrator

text: No matter what dowry or gift you demand, I will gladly pay it—just give me the girl as my wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But since Shechem had defiled their sister, Dinah, Jacob’s sons responded deceitfully to Shechem and his father, Hamor.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to them, “We couldn’t possibly allow this, because you’re not circumcised. It would be a disgrace for our sister to marry a man like you!
speaker: Narrator

text: But here is a solution. If every man among you will be circumcised like we are,
speaker: Narrator

text: then we will give you our daughters, and we’ll take your daughters for ourselves. We will live among you and become one people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you don’t agree to be circumcised, we will take her and be on our way.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hamor and his son Shechem agreed to their proposal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shechem wasted no time in acting on this request, for he wanted Jacob’s daughter desperately. Shechem was a highly respected member of his family,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he went with his father, Hamor, to present this proposal to the leaders at the town gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These men are our friends,” they said. “Let’s invite them to live here among us and trade freely. Look, the land is large enough to hold them. We can take their daughters as wives and let them marry ours.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they will consider staying here and becoming one people with us only if all of our men are circumcised, just as they are.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if we do this, all their livestock and possessions will eventually be ours. Come, let’s agree to their terms and let them settle here among us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the men in the town council agreed with Hamor and Shechem, and every male in the town was circumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: But three days later, when their wounds were still sore, two of Jacob’s sons, Simeon and Levi, who were Dinah’s full brothers, took their swords and entered the town without opposition. Then they slaughtered every male there,
speaker: Narrator

text: including Hamor and his son Shechem. They killed them with their swords, then took Dinah from Shechem’s house and returned to their camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the rest of Jacob’s sons arrived. Finding the men slaughtered, they plundered the town because their sister had been defiled there.
speaker: Narrator

text: They seized all the flocks and herds and donkeys—everything they could lay their hands on, both inside the town and outside in the fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: They looted all their wealth and plundered their houses. They also took all their little children and wives and led them away as captives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward Jacob said to Simeon and Levi, “You have ruined me! You’ve made me stink among all the people of this land—among all the Canaanites and Perizzites. We are so few that they will join forces and crush us. I will be ruined, and my entire household will be wiped out!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “But why should we let him treat our sister like a prostitute?” they retorted angrily.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said to Jacob, “Get ready and move to Bethel and settle there. Build an altar there to the God who appeared to you when you fled from your brother, Esau.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob told everyone in his household, “Get rid of all your pagan idols, purify yourselves, and put on clean clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: We are now going to Bethel, where I will build an altar to the God who answered my prayers when I was in distress. He has been with me wherever I have gone.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they gave Jacob all their pagan idols and earrings, and he buried them under the great tree near Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they set out, a terror from God spread over the people in all the towns of that area, so no one attacked Jacob’s family.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eventually, Jacob and his household arrived at Luz (also called Bethel) in Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob built an altar there and named the place El-bethel (which means “God of Bethel”), because God had appeared to him there when he was fleeing from his brother, Esau.
speaker: Narrator

text: Soon after this, Rebekah’s old nurse, Deborah, died. She was buried beneath the oak tree in the valley below Bethel. Ever since, the tree has been called Allon-bacuth (which means “oak of weeping”).
speaker: Narrator

text: Now that Jacob had returned from Paddan-aram, God appeared to him again at Bethel. God blessed him,
speaker: Narrator

text: saying, “Your name is Jacob, but you will not be called Jacob any longer. From now on your name will be Israel.” So God renamed him Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “I am El-Shaddai—‘God Almighty.’ Be fruitful and multiply. You will become a great nation, even many nations. Kings will be among your descendants!
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will give you the land I once gave to Abraham and Isaac. Yes, I will give it to you and your descendants after you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God went up from the place where he had spoken to Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob set up a stone pillar to mark the place where God had spoken to him. Then he poured wine over it as an offering to God and anointed the pillar with olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jacob named the place Bethel (which means “house of God”), because God had spoken to him there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leaving Bethel, Jacob and his clan moved on toward Ephrath. But Rachel went into labor while they were still some distance away. Her labor pains were intense.
speaker: Narrator

text: After a very hard delivery, the midwife finally exclaimed, “Don’t be afraid—you have another son!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Rachel was about to die, but with her last breath she named the baby Ben-oni (which means “son of my sorrow”). The baby’s father, however, called him Benjamin (which means “son of my right hand”).
speaker: Narrator

text: So Rachel died and was buried on the way to Ephrath (that is, Bethlehem).
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob set up a stone monument over Rachel’s grave, and it can be seen there to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob traveled on and camped beyond Migdal-eder.
speaker: Narrator

text:
While he was living there, Reuben had intercourse with Bilhah, his father’s concubine, and Jacob soon heard about it.
These are the names of the twelve sons of Jacob:
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Leah were Reuben (Jacob’s oldest son), Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, and Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Rachel were Joseph and Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Bilhah, Rachel’s servant, were Dan and Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Zilpah, Leah’s servant, were Gad and Asher.
These are the names of the sons who were born to Jacob at Paddan-aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob returned to his father, Isaac, in Mamre, which is near Kiriath-arba (now called Hebron), where Abraham and Isaac had both lived as foreigners.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac lived for 180 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he breathed his last and died at a ripe old age, joining his ancestors in death. And his sons, Esau and Jacob, buried him.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the account of the descendants of Esau (also known as Edom).
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau married two young women from Canaan: Adah, the daughter of Elon the Hittite; and Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah and granddaughter of Zibeon the Hivite.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also married his cousin Basemath, who was the daughter of Ishmael and the sister of Nebaioth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adah gave birth to a son named Eliphaz for Esau. Basemath gave birth to a son named Reuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Oholibamah gave birth to sons named Jeush, Jalam, and Korah. All these sons were born to Esau in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau took his wives, his children, and his entire household, along with his livestock and cattle—all the wealth he had acquired in the land of Canaan—and moved away from his brother, Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was not enough land to support them both because of all the livestock and possessions they had acquired.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Esau (also known as Edom) settled in the hill country of Seir.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the account of Esau’s descendants, the Edomites, who lived in the hill country of Seir.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of Esau’s sons: Eliphaz, the son of Esau’s wife Adah; and Reuel, the son of Esau’s wife Basemath.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Eliphaz were Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam, and Kenaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: Timna, the concubine of Esau’s son Eliphaz, gave birth to a son named Amalek. These are the descendants of Esau’s wife Adah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Reuel were Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. These are the descendants of Esau’s wife Basemath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau also had sons through Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah and granddaughter of Zibeon. Their names were Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the descendants of Esau who became the leaders of various clans:
The descendants of Esau’s oldest son, Eliphaz, became the leaders of the clans of Teman, Omar, Zepho, Kenaz,
speaker: Narrator

text: Korah, Gatam, and Amalek. These are the clan leaders in the land of Edom who descended from Eliphaz. All these were descendants of Esau’s wife Adah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Esau’s son Reuel became the leaders of the clans of Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. These are the clan leaders in the land of Edom who descended from Reuel. All these were descendants of Esau’s wife Basemath.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Esau and his wife Oholibamah became the leaders of the clans of Jeush, Jalam, and Korah. These are the clan leaders who descended from Esau’s wife Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the clans descended from Esau (also known as Edom), identified by their clan leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of the tribes that descended from Seir the Horite. They lived in the land of Edom: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan. These were the Horite clan leaders, the descendants of Seir, who lived in the land of Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Lotan were Hori and Hemam. Lotan’s sister was named Timna.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Shobal were Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho, and Onam.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Zibeon were Aiah and Anah. (This is the Anah who discovered the hot springs in the wilderness while he was grazing his father’s donkeys.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Anah were his son, Dishon, and his daughter, Oholibamah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Dishon were Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Keran.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Ezer were Bilhan, Zaavan, and Akan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Dishan were Uz and Aran.
speaker: Narrator

text: So these were the leaders of the Horite clans: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan. The Horite clans are named after their clan leaders, who lived in the land of Seir.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the kings who ruled in the land of Edom before any king ruled over the Israelites:
speaker: Narrator

text: Bela son of Beor, who ruled in Edom from his city of Dinhabah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Bela died, Jobab son of Zerah from Bozrah became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jobab died, Husham from the land of the Temanites became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Husham died, Hadad son of Bedad became king in his place and ruled from the city of Avith. He was the one who defeated the Midianites in the land of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Hadad died, Samlah from the city of Masrekah became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Samlah died, Shaul from the city of Rehoboth-on-the-River became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Shaul died, Baal-hanan son of Acbor became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Baal-hanan son of Acbor died, Hadad became king in his place and ruled from the city of Pau. His wife was Mehetabel, the daughter of Matred and granddaughter of Me-zahab.
speaker: Narrator
