text: These are the names of the leaders of the clans descended from Esau, who lived in the places named for them: Timna, Alvah, Jetheth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Oholibamah, Elah, Pinon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kenaz, Teman, Mibzar,
speaker: Narrator

text: Magdiel, and Iram. These are the leaders of the clans of Edom, listed according to their settlements in the land they occupied. They all descended from Esau, the ancestor of the Edomites.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob settled again in the land of Canaan, where his father had lived as a foreigner.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the account of Jacob and his family. When Joseph was seventeen years old, he often tended his father’s flocks. He worked for his half brothers, the sons of his father’s wives Bilhah and Zilpah. But Joseph reported to his father some of the bad things his brothers were doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob loved Joseph more than any of his other children because Joseph had been born to him in his old age. So one day Jacob had a special gift made for Joseph—a beautiful robe.
speaker: Narrator

text: But his brothers hated Joseph because their father loved him more than the rest of them. They couldn’t say a kind word to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: One night Joseph had a dream, and when he told his brothers about it, they hated him more than ever.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Listen to this dream,” he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: “We were out in the field, tying up bundles of grain. Suddenly my bundle stood up, and your bundles all gathered around and bowed low before mine!”
speaker: Narrator

text: His brothers responded, “So you think you will be our king, do you? Do you actually think you will reign over us?” And they hated him all the more because of his dreams and the way he talked about them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Soon Joseph had another dream, and again he told his brothers about it. “Listen, I have had another dream,” he said. “The sun, moon, and eleven stars bowed low before me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: This time he told the dream to his father as well as to his brothers, but his father scolded him. “What kind of dream is that?” he asked. “Will your mother and I and your brothers actually come and bow to the ground before you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But while his brothers were jealous of Joseph, his father wondered what the dreams meant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Soon after this, Joseph’s brothers went to pasture their father’s flocks at Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When they had been gone for some time, Jacob said to Joseph, “Your brothers are pasturing the sheep at Shechem. Get ready, and I will send you to them.”
“I’m ready to go,” Joseph replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go and see how your brothers and the flocks are getting along,” Jacob said. “Then come back and bring me a report.” So Jacob sent him on his way, and Joseph traveled to Shechem from their home in the valley of Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he arrived there, a man from the area noticed him wandering around the countryside. “What are you looking for?” he asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’m looking for my brothers,” Joseph replied. “Do you know where they are pasturing their sheep?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yes,” the man told him. “They have moved on from here, but I heard them say, ‘Let’s go on to Dothan.’” So Joseph followed his brothers to Dothan and found them there.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph’s brothers saw him coming, they recognized him in the distance. As he approached, they made plans to kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Here comes the dreamer!” they said.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Come on, let’s kill him and throw him into one of these cisterns. We can tell our father, ‘A wild animal has eaten him.’ Then we’ll see what becomes of his dreams!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Reuben heard of their scheme, he came to Joseph’s rescue. “Let’s not kill him,” he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why should we shed any blood? Let’s just throw him into this empty cistern here in the wilderness. Then he’ll die without our laying a hand on him.” Reuben was secretly planning to rescue Joseph and return him to his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when Joseph arrived, his brothers ripped off the beautiful robe he was wearing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they grabbed him and threw him into the cistern. Now the cistern was empty; there was no water in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, just as they were sitting down to eat, they looked up and saw a caravan of camels in the distance coming toward them. It was a group of Ishmaelite traders taking a load of gum, balm, and aromatic resin from Gilead down to Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah said to his brothers, “What will we gain by killing our brother? We’d have to cover up the crime.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead of hurting him, let’s sell him to those Ishmaelite traders. After all, he is our brother—our own flesh and blood!” And his brothers agreed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when the Ishmaelites, who were Midianite traders, came by, Joseph’s brothers pulled him out of the cistern and sold him to them for twenty pieces of silver. And the traders took him to Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, Reuben returned to get Joseph out of the cistern. When he discovered that Joseph was missing, he tore his clothes in grief.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he went back to his brothers and lamented, “The boy is gone! What will I do now?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the brothers killed a young goat and dipped Joseph’s robe in its blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: They sent the beautiful robe to their father with this message: “Look at what we found. Doesn’t this robe belong to your son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Their father recognized it immediately. “Yes,” he said, “it is my son’s robe. A wild animal must have eaten him. Joseph has clearly been torn to pieces!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob tore his clothes and dressed himself in burlap. He mourned deeply for his son for a long time.
speaker: Narrator

text: His family all tried to comfort him, but he refused to be comforted. “I will go to my grave mourning for my son,” he would say, and then he would weep.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the Midianite traders arrived in Egypt, where they sold Joseph to Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh, the king of Egypt. Potiphar was captain of the palace guard.
speaker: Narrator

text: About this time, Judah left home and moved to Adullam, where he stayed with a man named Hirah.
speaker: Narrator

text: There he saw a Canaanite woman, the daughter of Shua, and he married her. When he slept with her,
speaker: Narrator

text: she became pregnant and gave birth to a son, and he named the boy Er.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she became pregnant again and gave birth to another son, and she named him Onan.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when she gave birth to a third son, she named him Shelah. At the time of Shelah’s birth, they were living at Kezib.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the course of time, Judah arranged for his firstborn son, Er, to marry a young woman named Tamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Er was a wicked man in the Lord’s sight, so the Lord took his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Judah said to Er’s brother Onan, “Go and marry Tamar, as our law requires of the brother of a man who has died. You must produce an heir for your brother.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Onan was not willing to have a child who would not be his own heir. So whenever he had intercourse with his brother’s wife, he spilled the semen on the ground. This prevented her from having a child who would belong to his brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord considered it evil for Onan to deny a child to his dead brother. So the Lord took Onan’s life, too.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Judah said to Tamar, his daughter-in-law, “Go back to your parents’ home and remain a widow until my son Shelah is old enough to marry you.” (But Judah didn’t really intend to do this because he was afraid Shelah would also die, like his two brothers.) So Tamar went back to live in her father’s home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some years later Judah’s wife died. After the time of mourning was over, Judah and his friend Hirah the Adullamite went up to Timnah to supervise the shearing of his sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: Someone told Tamar, “Look, your father-in-law is going up to Timnah to shear his sheep.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Tamar was aware that Shelah had grown up, but no arrangements had been made for her to come and marry him. So she changed out of her widow’s clothing and covered herself with a veil to disguise herself. Then she sat beside the road at the entrance to the village of Enaim, which is on the road to Timnah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah noticed her and thought she was a prostitute, since she had covered her face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he stopped and propositioned her. “Let me have sex with you,” he said, not realizing that she was his own daughter-in-law.
“How much will you pay to have sex with me?” Tamar asked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I’ll send you a young goat from my flock,” Judah promised.
“But what will you give me to guarantee that you will send the goat?” she asked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What kind of guarantee do you want?” he replied.
She answered, “Leave me your identification seal and its cord and the walking stick you are carrying.” So Judah gave them to her. Then he had intercourse with her, and she became pregnant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward she went back home, took off her veil, and put on her widow’s clothing as usual.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later Judah asked his friend Hirah the Adullamite to take the young goat to the woman and to pick up the things he had given her as his guarantee. But Hirah couldn’t find her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he asked the men who lived there, “Where can I find the shrine prostitute who was sitting beside the road at the entrance to Enaim?”
“We’ve never had a shrine prostitute here,” they replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hirah returned to Judah and told him, “I couldn’t find her anywhere, and the men of the village claim they’ve never had a shrine prostitute there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then let her keep the things I gave her,” Judah said. “I sent the young goat as we agreed, but you couldn’t find her. We’d be the laughingstock of the village if we went back again to look for her.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
About three months later, Judah was told, “Tamar, your daughter-in-law, has acted like a prostitute. And now, because of this, she’s pregnant.”
“Bring her out, and let her be burned!” Judah demanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as they were taking her out to kill her, she sent this message to her father-in-law: “The man who owns these things made me pregnant. Look closely. Whose seal and cord and walking stick are these?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah recognized them immediately and said, “She is more righteous than I am, because I didn’t arrange for her to marry my son Shelah.” And Judah never slept with Tamar again.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the time came for Tamar to give birth, it was discovered that she was carrying twins.
speaker: Narrator

text: While she was in labor, one of the babies reached out his hand. The midwife grabbed it and tied a scarlet string around the child’s wrist, announcing, “This one came out first.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But then he pulled back his hand, and out came his brother! “What!” the midwife exclaimed. “How did you break out first?” So he was named Perez.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the baby with the scarlet string on his wrist was born, and he was named Zerah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph was taken to Egypt by the Ishmaelite traders, he was purchased by Potiphar, an Egyptian officer. Potiphar was captain of the guard for Pharaoh, the king of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was with Joseph, so he succeeded in everything he did as he served in the home of his Egyptian master.
speaker: Narrator

text: Potiphar noticed this and realized that the Lord was with Joseph, giving him success in everything he did.
speaker: Narrator

text: This pleased Potiphar, so he soon made Joseph his personal attendant. He put him in charge of his entire household and everything he owned.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the day Joseph was put in charge of his master’s household and property, the Lord began to bless Potiphar’s household for Joseph’s sake. All his household affairs ran smoothly, and his crops and livestock flourished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Potiphar gave Joseph complete administrative responsibility over everything he owned. With Joseph there, he didn’t worry about a thing—except what kind of food to eat!
Joseph was a very handsome and well-built young man,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Potiphar’s wife soon began to look at him lustfully. “Come and sleep with me,” she demanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joseph refused. “Look,” he told her, “my master trusts me with everything in his entire household.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one here has more authority than I do. He has held back nothing from me except you, because you are his wife. How could I do such a wicked thing? It would be a great sin against God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She kept putting pressure on Joseph day after day, but he refused to sleep with her, and he kept out of her way as much as possible.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day, however, no one else was around when he went in to do his work.
speaker: Narrator

text: She came and grabbed him by his cloak, demanding, “Come on, sleep with me!” Joseph tore himself away, but he left his cloak in her hand as he ran from the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she saw that she was holding his cloak and he had fled,
speaker: Narrator

text: she called out to her servants. Soon all the men came running. “Look!” she said. “My husband has brought this Hebrew slave here to make fools of us! He came into my room to rape me, but I screamed.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he heard me scream, he ran outside and got away, but he left his cloak behind with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She kept the cloak with her until her husband came home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she told him her story. “That Hebrew slave you’ve brought into our house tried to come in and fool around with me,” she said.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But when I screamed, he ran outside, leaving his cloak with me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Potiphar was furious when he heard his wife’s story about how Joseph had treated her.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he took Joseph and threw him into the prison where the king’s prisoners were held, and there he remained.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord was with Joseph in the prison and showed him his faithful love. And the Lord made Joseph a favorite with the prison warden.
speaker: Narrator

text: Before long, the warden put Joseph in charge of all the other prisoners and over everything that happened in the prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: The warden had no more worries, because Joseph took care of everything. The Lord was with him and caused everything he did to succeed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, Pharaoh’s chief cup-bearer and chief baker offended their royal master.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh became angry with these two officials,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he put them in the prison where Joseph was, in the palace of the captain of the guard.
speaker: Narrator

text: They remained in prison for quite some time, and the captain of the guard assigned them to Joseph, who looked after them.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were in prison, Pharaoh’s cup-bearer and baker each had a dream one night, and each dream had its own meaning.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph saw them the next morning, he noticed that they both looked upset.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why do you look so worried today?” he asked them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And they replied, “We both had dreams last night, but no one can tell us what they mean.”
“Interpreting dreams is God’s business,” Joseph replied. “Go ahead and tell me your dreams.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the chief cup-bearer told Joseph his dream first. “In my dream,” he said, “I saw a grapevine in front of me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The vine had three branches that began to bud and blossom, and soon it produced clusters of ripe grapes.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was holding Pharaoh’s wine cup in my hand, so I took a cluster of grapes and squeezed the juice into the cup. Then I placed the cup in Pharaoh’s hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the dream means,” Joseph said. “The three branches represent three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Within three days Pharaoh will lift you up and restore you to your position as his chief cup-bearer.
speaker: Narrator

text: And please remember me and do me a favor when things go well for you. Mention me to Pharaoh, so he might let me out of this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I was kidnapped from my homeland, the land of the Hebrews, and now I’m here in prison, but I did nothing to deserve it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the chief baker saw that Joseph had given the first dream such a positive interpretation, he said to Joseph, “I had a dream, too. In my dream there were three baskets of white pastries stacked on my head.
speaker: Narrator

text: The top basket contained all kinds of pastries for Pharaoh, but the birds came and ate them from the basket on my head.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the dream means,” Joseph told him. “The three baskets also represent three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three days from now Pharaoh will lift you up and impale your body on a pole. Then birds will come and peck away at your flesh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh’s birthday came three days later, and he prepared a banquet for all his officials and staff. He summoned his chief cup-bearer and chief baker to join the other officials.
speaker: Narrator

text: He then restored the chief cup-bearer to his former position, so he could again hand Pharaoh his cup.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Pharaoh impaled the chief baker, just as Joseph had predicted when he interpreted his dream.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh’s chief cup-bearer, however, forgot all about Joseph, never giving him another thought.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two full years later, Pharaoh dreamed that he was standing on the bank of the Nile River.
speaker: Narrator

text: In his dream he saw seven fat, healthy cows come up out of the river and begin grazing in the marsh grass.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he saw seven more cows come up behind them from the Nile, but these were scrawny and thin. These cows stood beside the fat cows on the riverbank.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the scrawny, thin cows ate the seven healthy, fat cows! At this point in the dream, Pharaoh woke up.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he fell asleep again and had a second dream. This time he saw seven heads of grain, plump and beautiful, growing on a single stalk.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then seven more heads of grain appeared, but these were shriveled and withered by the east wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: And these thin heads swallowed up the seven plump, well-formed heads! Then Pharaoh woke up again and realized it was a dream.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next morning Pharaoh was very disturbed by the dreams. So he called for all the magicians and wise men of Egypt. When Pharaoh told them his dreams, not one of them could tell him what they meant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, the king’s chief cup-bearer spoke up. “Today I have been reminded of my failure,” he told Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Some time ago, you were angry with the chief baker and me, and you imprisoned us in the palace of the captain of the guard.
speaker: Narrator

text: One night the chief baker and I each had a dream, and each dream had its own meaning.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a young Hebrew man with us in the prison who was a slave of the captain of the guard. We told him our dreams, and he told us what each of our dreams meant.
speaker: Narrator

text: And everything happened just as he had predicted. I was restored to my position as cup-bearer, and the chief baker was executed and impaled on a pole.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh sent for Joseph at once, and he was quickly brought from the prison. After he shaved and changed his clothes, he went in and stood before Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, “I had a dream last night, and no one here can tell me what it means. But I have heard that when you hear about a dream you can interpret it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “It is beyond my power to do this,” Joseph replied. “But God can tell you what it means and set you at ease.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Pharaoh told Joseph his dream. “In my dream,” he said, “I was standing on the bank of the Nile River,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I saw seven fat, healthy cows come up out of the river and begin grazing in the marsh grass.
speaker: Narrator

text: But then I saw seven sick-looking cows, scrawny and thin, come up after them. I’ve never seen such sorry-looking animals in all the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: These thin, scrawny cows ate the seven fat cows.
speaker: Narrator

text: But afterward you wouldn’t have known it, for they were still as thin and scrawny as before! Then I woke up.
speaker: Narrator

text: “In my dream I also saw seven heads of grain, full and beautiful, growing on a single stalk.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then seven more heads of grain appeared, but these were blighted, shriveled, and withered by the east wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the shriveled heads swallowed the seven healthy heads. I told these dreams to the magicians, but no one could tell me what they mean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph responded, “Both of Pharaoh’s dreams mean the same thing. God is telling Pharaoh in advance what he is about to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seven healthy cows and the seven healthy heads of grain both represent seven years of prosperity.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seven thin, scrawny cows that came up later and the seven thin heads of grain, withered by the east wind, represent seven years of famine.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This will happen just as I have described it, for God has revealed to Pharaoh in advance what he is about to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next seven years will be a period of great prosperity throughout the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But afterward there will be seven years of famine so great that all the prosperity will be forgotten in Egypt. Famine will destroy the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: This famine will be so severe that even the memory of the good years will be erased.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for having two similar dreams, it means that these events have been decreed by God, and he will soon make them happen.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore, Pharaoh should find an intelligent and wise man and put him in charge of the entire land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh should appoint supervisors over the land and let them collect one-fifth of all the crops during the seven good years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have them gather all the food produced in the good years that are just ahead and bring it to Pharaoh’s storehouses. Store it away, and guard it so there will be food in the cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: That way there will be enough to eat when the seven years of famine come to the land of Egypt. Otherwise this famine will destroy the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph’s suggestions were well received by Pharaoh and his officials.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Pharaoh asked his officials, “Can we find anyone else like this man so obviously filled with the spirit of God?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Since God has revealed the meaning of the dreams to you, clearly no one else is as intelligent or wise as you are.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be in charge of my court, and all my people will take orders from you. Only I, sitting on my throne, will have a rank higher than yours.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, “I hereby put you in charge of the entire land of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh removed his signet ring from his hand and placed it on Joseph’s finger. He dressed him in fine linen clothing and hung a gold chain around his neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he had Joseph ride in the chariot reserved for his second-in-command. And wherever Joseph went, the command was shouted, “Kneel down!” So Pharaoh put Joseph in charge of all Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Pharaoh said to him, “I am Pharaoh, but no one will lift a hand or foot in the entire land of Egypt without your approval.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh gave Joseph a new Egyptian name, Zaphenath-paneah. He also gave him a wife, whose name was Asenath. She was the daughter of Potiphera, the priest of On. So Joseph took charge of the entire land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was thirty years old when he began serving in the court of Pharaoh, the king of Egypt. And when Joseph left Pharaoh’s presence, he inspected the entire land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: As predicted, for seven years the land produced bumper crops.
speaker: Narrator

text: During those years, Joseph gathered all the crops grown in Egypt and stored the grain from the surrounding fields in the cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: He piled up huge amounts of grain like sand on the seashore. Finally, he stopped keeping records because there was too much to measure.
speaker: Narrator

text: During this time, before the first of the famine years, two sons were born to Joseph and his wife, Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera, the priest of On.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph named his older son Manasseh, for he said, “God has made me forget all my troubles and everyone in my father’s family.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph named his second son Ephraim, for he said, “God has made me fruitful in this land of my grief.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At last the seven years of bumper crops throughout the land of Egypt came to an end.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the seven years of famine began, just as Joseph had predicted. The famine also struck all the surrounding countries, but throughout Egypt there was plenty of food.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eventually, however, the famine spread throughout the land of Egypt as well. And when the people cried out to Pharaoh for food, he told them, “Go to Joseph, and do whatever he tells you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So with severe famine everywhere, Joseph opened up the storehouses and distributed grain to the Egyptians, for the famine was severe throughout the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: And people from all around came to Egypt to buy grain from Joseph because the famine was severe throughout the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob heard that grain was available in Egypt, he said to his sons, “Why are you standing around looking at one another?
speaker: Narrator

text: I have heard there is grain in Egypt. Go down there, and buy enough grain to keep us alive. Otherwise we’ll die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph’s ten older brothers went down to Egypt to buy grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob wouldn’t let Joseph’s younger brother, Benjamin, go with them, for fear some harm might come to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob’s sons arrived in Egypt along with others to buy food, for the famine was in Canaan as well.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since Joseph was governor of all Egypt and in charge of selling grain to all the people, it was to him that his brothers came. When they arrived, they bowed before him with their faces to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Joseph recognized his brothers instantly, but he pretended to be a stranger and spoke harshly to them. “Where are you from?” he demanded.
“From the land of Canaan,” they replied. “We have come to buy food.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Although Joseph recognized his brothers, they didn’t recognize him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he remembered the dreams he’d had about them many years before. He said to them, “You are spies! You have come to see how vulnerable our land has become.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “No, my lord!” they exclaimed. “Your servants have simply come to buy food.
speaker: Narrator

text: We are all brothers—members of the same family. We are honest men, sir! We are not spies!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yes, you are!” Joseph insisted. “You have come to see how vulnerable our land has become.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Sir,” they said, “there are actually twelve of us. We, your servants, are all brothers, sons of a man living in the land of Canaan. Our youngest brother is back there with our father right now, and one of our brothers is no longer with us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joseph insisted, “As I said, you are spies!
speaker: Narrator

text: This is how I will test your story. I swear by the life of Pharaoh that you will never leave Egypt unless your youngest brother comes here!
speaker: Narrator

text: One of you must go and get your brother. I’ll keep the rest of you here in prison. Then we’ll find out whether or not your story is true. By the life of Pharaoh, if it turns out that you don’t have a younger brother, then I’ll know you are spies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph put them all in prison for three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the third day Joseph said to them, “I am a God-fearing man. If you do as I say, you will live.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you really are honest men, choose one of your brothers to remain in prison. The rest of you may go home with grain for your starving families.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must bring your youngest brother back to me. This will prove that you are telling the truth, and you will not die.” To this they agreed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Speaking among themselves, they said, “Clearly we are being punished because of what we did to Joseph long ago. We saw his anguish when he pleaded for his life, but we wouldn’t listen. That’s why we’re in this trouble.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Didn’t I tell you not to sin against the boy?” Reuben asked. “But you wouldn’t listen. And now we have to answer for his blood!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Of course, they didn’t know that Joseph understood them, for he had been speaking to them through an interpreter.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now he turned away from them and began to weep. When he regained his composure, he spoke to them again. Then he chose Simeon from among them and had him tied up right before their eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph then ordered his servants to fill the men’s sacks with grain, but he also gave secret instructions to return each brother’s payment at the top of his sack. He also gave them supplies for their journey home.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the brothers loaded their donkeys with the grain and headed for home.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they stopped for the night and one of them opened his sack to get grain for his donkey, he found his money in the top of his sack.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look!” he exclaimed to his brothers. “My money has been returned; it’s here in my sack!” Then their hearts sank. Trembling, they said to each other, “What has God done to us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the brothers came to their father, Jacob, in the land of Canaan, they told him everything that had happened to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The man who is governor of the land spoke very harshly to us,” they told him. “He accused us of being spies scouting the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we said, ‘We are honest men, not spies.
speaker: Narrator

text: We are twelve brothers, sons of one father. One brother is no longer with us, and the youngest is at home with our father in the land of Canaan.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the man who is governor of the land told us, ‘This is how I will find out if you are honest men. Leave one of your brothers here with me, and take grain for your starving families and go on home.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must bring your youngest brother back to me. Then I will know you are honest men and not spies. Then I will give you back your brother, and you may trade freely in the land.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: As they emptied out their sacks, there in each man’s sack was the bag of money he had paid for the grain! The brothers and their father were terrified when they saw the bags of money.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob exclaimed, “You are robbing me of my children! Joseph is gone! Simeon is gone! And now you want to take Benjamin, too. Everything is going against me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Reuben said to his father, “You may kill my two sons if I don’t bring Benjamin back to you. I’ll be responsible for him, and I promise to bring him back.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob replied, “My son will not go down with you. His brother Joseph is dead, and he is all I have left. If anything should happen to him on your journey, you would send this grieving, white-haired man to his grave.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the famine continued to ravage the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the grain they had brought from Egypt was almost gone, Jacob said to his sons, “Go back and buy us a little more food.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Judah said, “The man was serious when he warned us, ‘You won’t see my face again unless your brother is with you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: If you send Benjamin with us, we will go down and buy more food.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you don’t let Benjamin go, we won’t go either. Remember, the man said, ‘You won’t see my face again unless your brother is with you.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why were you so cruel to me?” Jacob moaned. “Why did you tell him you had another brother?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “The man kept asking us questions about our family,” they replied. “He asked, ‘Is your father still alive? Do you have another brother?’ So we answered his questions. How could we know he would say, ‘Bring your brother down here’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah said to his father, “Send the boy with me, and we will be on our way. Otherwise we will all die of starvation—and not only we, but you and our little ones.
speaker: Narrator

text: I personally guarantee his safety. You may hold me responsible if I don’t bring him back to you. Then let me bear the blame forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: If we hadn’t wasted all this time, we could have gone and returned twice by now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So their father, Jacob, finally said to them, “If it can’t be avoided, then at least do this. Pack your bags with the best products of this land. Take them down to the man as gifts—balm, honey, gum, aromatic resin, pistachio nuts, and almonds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also take double the money that was put back in your sacks, as it was probably someone’s mistake.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then take your brother, and go back to the man.
speaker: Narrator

text: May God Almighty give you mercy as you go before the man, so that he will release Simeon and let Benjamin return. But if I must lose my children, so be it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the men packed Jacob’s gifts and double the money and headed off with Benjamin. They finally arrived in Egypt and presented themselves to Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph saw Benjamin with them, he said to the manager of his household, “These men will eat with me this noon. Take them inside the palace. Then go slaughter an animal, and prepare a big feast.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the man did as Joseph told him and took them into Joseph’s palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: The brothers were terrified when they saw that they were being taken into Joseph’s house. “It’s because of the money someone put in our sacks last time we were here,” they said. “He plans to pretend that we stole it. Then he will seize us, make us slaves, and take our donkeys.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The brothers approached the manager of Joseph’s household and spoke to him at the entrance to the palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Sir,” they said, “we came to Egypt once before to buy food.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as we were returning home, we stopped for the night and opened our sacks. Then we discovered that each man’s money—the exact amount paid—was in the top of his sack! Here it is; we have brought it back with us.
speaker: Narrator

text: We also have additional money to buy more food. We have no idea who put our money in our sacks.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Relax. Don’t be afraid,” the household manager told them. “Your God, the God of your father, must have put this treasure into your sacks. I know I received your payment.” Then he released Simeon and brought him out to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The manager then led the men into Joseph’s palace. He gave them water to wash their feet and provided food for their donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were told they would be eating there, so they prepared their gifts for Joseph’s arrival at noon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph came home, they gave him the gifts they had brought him, then bowed low to the ground before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After greeting them, he asked, “How is your father, the old man you spoke about? Is he still alive?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yes,” they replied. “Our father, your servant, is alive and well.” And they bowed low again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph looked at his brother Benjamin, the son of his own mother. “Is this your youngest brother, the one you told me about?” Joseph asked. “May God be gracious to you, my son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph hurried from the room because he was overcome with emotion for his brother. He went into his private room, where he broke down and wept.
speaker: Narrator

text: After washing his face, he came back out, keeping himself under control. Then he ordered, “Bring out the food!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The waiters served Joseph at his own table, and his brothers were served at a separate table. The Egyptians who ate with Joseph sat at their own table, because Egyptians despise Hebrews and refuse to eat with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph told each of his brothers where to sit, and to their amazement, he seated them according to age, from oldest to youngest.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Joseph filled their plates with food from his own table, giving Benjamin five times as much as he gave the others. So they feasted and drank freely with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When his brothers were ready to leave, Joseph gave these instructions to his palace manager: “Fill each of their sacks with as much grain as they can carry, and put each man’s money back into his sack.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then put my personal silver cup at the top of the youngest brother’s sack, along with the money for his grain.” So the manager did as Joseph instructed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The brothers were up at dawn and were sent on their journey with their loaded donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they had gone only a short distance and were barely out of the city, Joseph said to his palace manager, “Chase after them and stop them. When you catch up with them, ask them, ‘Why have you repaid my kindness with such evil?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why have you stolen my master’s silver cup, which he uses to predict the future? What a wicked thing you have done!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the palace manager caught up with the men, he spoke to them as he had been instructed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “What are you talking about?” the brothers responded. “We are your servants and would never do such a thing!
speaker: Narrator

text: Didn’t we return the money we found in our sacks? We brought it back all the way from the land of Canaan. Why would we steal silver or gold from your master’s house?
speaker: Narrator

text: If you find his cup with any one of us, let that man die. And all the rest of us, my lord, will be your slaves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “That’s fair,” the man replied. “But only the one who stole the cup will be my slave. The rest of you may go free.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They all quickly took their sacks from the backs of their donkeys and opened them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The palace manager searched the brothers’ sacks, from the oldest to the youngest. And the cup was found in Benjamin’s sack!
speaker: Narrator

text: When the brothers saw this, they tore their clothing in despair. Then they loaded their donkeys again and returned to the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph was still in his palace when Judah and his brothers arrived, and they fell to the ground before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “What have you done?” Joseph demanded. “Don’t you know that a man like me can predict the future?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah answered, “Oh, my lord, what can we say to you? How can we explain this? How can we prove our innocence? God is punishing us for our sins. My lord, we have all returned to be your slaves—all of us, not just our brother who had your cup in his sack.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “No,” Joseph said. “I would never do such a thing! Only the man who stole the cup will be my slave. The rest of you may go back to your father in peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Judah stepped forward and said, “Please, my lord, let your servant say just one word to you. Please, do not be angry with me, even though you are as powerful as Pharaoh himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: “My lord, previously you asked us, your servants, ‘Do you have a father or a brother?’
speaker: Narrator

text: And we responded, ‘Yes, my lord, we have a father who is an old man, and his youngest son is a child of his old age. His full brother is dead, and he alone is left of his mother’s children, and his father loves him very much.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “And you said to us, ‘Bring him here so I can see him with my own eyes.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But we said to you, ‘My lord, the boy cannot leave his father, for his father would die.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But you told us, ‘Unless your youngest brother comes with you, you will never see my face again.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So we returned to your servant, our father, and told him what you had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, when he said, ‘Go back again and buy us more food,’
speaker: Narrator

text: we replied, ‘We can’t go unless you let our youngest brother go with us. We’ll never get to see the man’s face unless our youngest brother is with us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then my father said to us, ‘As you know, my wife had two sons,
speaker: Narrator

text: and one of them went away and never returned. Doubtless he was torn to pieces by some wild animal. I have never seen him since.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if you take his brother away from me, and any harm comes to him, you will send this grieving, white-haired man to his grave.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “And now, my lord, I cannot go back to my father without the boy. Our father’s life is bound up in the boy’s life.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he sees that the boy is not with us, our father will die. We, your servants, will indeed be responsible for sending that grieving, white-haired man to his grave.
speaker: Narrator

text: My lord, I guaranteed to my father that I would take care of the boy. I told him, ‘If I don’t bring him back to you, I will bear the blame forever.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So please, my lord, let me stay here as a slave instead of the boy, and let the boy return with his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: For how can I return to my father if the boy is not with me? I couldn’t bear to see the anguish this would cause my father!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph could stand it no longer. There were many people in the room, and he said to his attendants, “Out, all of you!” So he was alone with his brothers when he told them who he was.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he broke down and wept. He wept so loudly the Egyptians could hear him, and word of it quickly carried to Pharaoh’s palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am Joseph!” he said to his brothers. “Is my father still alive?” But his brothers were speechless! They were stunned to realize that Joseph was standing there in front of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Please, come closer,” he said to them. So they came closer. And he said again, “I am Joseph, your brother, whom you sold into slavery in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But don’t be upset, and don’t be angry with yourselves for selling me to this place. It was God who sent me here ahead of you to preserve your lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: This famine that has ravaged the land for two years will last five more years, and there will be neither plowing nor harvesting.
speaker: Narrator

text: God has sent me ahead of you to keep you and your families alive and to preserve many survivors.
speaker: Narrator

text: So it was God who sent me here, not you! And he is the one who made me an adviser to Pharaoh—the manager of his entire palace and the governor of all Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now hurry back to my father and tell him, ‘This is what your son Joseph says: God has made me master over all the land of Egypt. So come down to me immediately!
speaker: Narrator

text: You can live in the region of Goshen, where you can be near me with all your children and grandchildren, your flocks and herds, and everything you own.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will take care of you there, for there are still five years of famine ahead of us. Otherwise you, your household, and all your animals will starve.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph added, “Look! You can see for yourselves, and so can my brother Benjamin, that I really am Joseph!
speaker: Narrator

text: Go tell my father of my honored position here in Egypt. Describe for him everything you have seen, and then bring my father here quickly.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Weeping with joy, he embraced Benjamin, and Benjamin did the same.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph kissed each of his brothers and wept over them, and after that they began talking freely with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The news soon reached Pharaoh’s palace: “Joseph’s brothers have arrived!” Pharaoh and his officials were all delighted to hear this.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Tell your brothers, ‘This is what you must do: Load your pack animals, and hurry back to the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then get your father and all of your families, and return here to me. I will give you the very best land in Egypt, and you will eat from the best that the land produces.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Tell your brothers, ‘Take wagons from the land of Egypt to carry your little children and your wives, and bring your father here.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t worry about your personal belongings, for the best of all the land of Egypt is yours.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the sons of Jacob did as they were told. Joseph provided them with wagons, as Pharaoh had commanded, and he gave them supplies for the journey.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he gave each of them new clothes—but to Benjamin he gave five changes of clothes and 300 pieces of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also sent his father ten male donkeys loaded with the finest products of Egypt, and ten female donkeys loaded with grain and bread and other supplies he would need on his journey.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph sent his brothers off, and as they left, he called after them, “Don’t quarrel about all this along the way!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they left Egypt and returned to their father, Jacob, in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Joseph is still alive!” they told him. “And he is governor of all the land of Egypt!” Jacob was stunned at the news—he couldn’t believe it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they repeated to Jacob everything Joseph had told them, and when he saw the wagons Joseph had sent to carry him, their father’s spirits revived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob exclaimed, “It must be true! My son Joseph is alive! I must go and see him before I die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob set out for Egypt with all his possessions. And when he came to Beersheba, he offered sacrifices to the God of his father, Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text:
During the night God spoke to him in a vision. “Jacob! Jacob!” he called.
“Here I am,” Jacob replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am God, the God of your father,” the voice said. “Do not be afraid to go down to Egypt, for there I will make your family into a great nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will go with you down to Egypt, and I will bring you back again. You will die in Egypt, but Joseph will be with you to close your eyes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob left Beersheba, and his sons took him to Egypt. They carried him and their little ones and their wives in the wagons Pharaoh had provided for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also took all their livestock and all the personal belongings they had acquired in the land of Canaan. So Jacob and his entire family went to Egypt—
speaker: Narrator

text: sons and grandsons, daughters and granddaughters—all his descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the names of the descendants of Israel—the sons of Jacob—who went to Egypt:
Reuben was Jacob’s oldest son.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Reuben were Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Simeon were Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jakin, Zohar, and Shaul. (Shaul’s mother was a Canaanite woman.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Levi were Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Judah were Er, Onan, Shelah, Perez, and Zerah (though Er and Onan had died in the land of Canaan). The sons of Perez were Hezron and Hamul.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Issachar were Tola, Puah, Jashub, and Shimron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Zebulun were Sered, Elon, and Jahleel.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the sons of Leah and Jacob who were born in Paddan-aram, in addition to their daughter, Dinah. The number of Jacob’s descendants (male and female) through Leah was thirty-three.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Gad were Zephon, Haggi, Shuni, Ezbon, Eri, Arodi, and Areli.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Asher were Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, and Beriah. Their sister was Serah. Beriah’s sons were Heber and Malkiel.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the sons of Zilpah, the servant given to Leah by her father, Laban. The number of Jacob’s descendants through Zilpah was sixteen.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Jacob’s wife Rachel were Joseph and Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph’s sons, born in the land of Egypt, were Manasseh and Ephraim. Their mother was Asenath, daughter of Potiphera, the priest of On.
speaker: Narrator

text: Benjamin’s sons were Bela, Beker, Ashbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Rosh, Muppim, Huppim, and Ard.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the sons of Rachel and Jacob. The number of Jacob’s descendants through Rachel was fourteen.
speaker: Narrator

text: The son of Dan was Hushim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Naphtali were Jahzeel, Guni, Jezer, and Shillem.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the sons of Bilhah, the servant given to Rachel by her father, Laban. The number of Jacob’s descendants through Bilhah was seven.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of Jacob’s direct descendants who went with him to Egypt, not counting his sons’ wives, was sixty-six.
speaker: Narrator

text: In addition, Joseph had two sons who were born in Egypt. So altogether, there were seventy members of Jacob’s family in the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they neared their destination, Jacob sent Judah ahead to meet Joseph and get directions to the region of Goshen. And when they finally arrived there,
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph prepared his chariot and traveled to Goshen to meet his father, Jacob. When Joseph arrived, he embraced his father and wept, holding him for a long time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, Jacob said to Joseph, “Now I am ready to die, since I have seen your face again and know you are still alive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Joseph said to his brothers and to his father’s entire family, “I will go to Pharaoh and tell him, ‘My brothers and my father’s entire family have come to me from the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These men are shepherds, and they raise livestock. They have brought with them their flocks and herds and everything they own.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “When Pharaoh calls for you and asks you about your occupation,
speaker: Narrator

text: you must tell him, ‘We, your servants, have raised livestock all our lives, as our ancestors have always done.’ When you tell him this, he will let you live here in the region of Goshen, for the Egyptians despise shepherds.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph went to see Pharaoh and told him, “My father and my brothers have arrived from the land of Canaan. They have come with all their flocks and herds and possessions, and they are now in the region of Goshen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph took five of his brothers with him and presented them to Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And Pharaoh asked the brothers, “What is your occupation?”
They replied, “We, your servants, are shepherds, just like our ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have come to live here in Egypt for a while, for there is no pasture for our flocks in Canaan. The famine is very severe there. So please, we request permission to live in the region of Goshen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Now that your father and brothers have joined you here,
speaker: Narrator

text: choose any place in the entire land of Egypt for them to live. Give them the best land of Egypt. Let them live in the region of Goshen. And if any of them have special skills, put them in charge of my livestock, too.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph brought in his father, Jacob, and presented him to Pharaoh. And Jacob blessed Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “How old are you?” Pharaoh asked him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob replied, “I have traveled this earth for 130 hard years. But my life has been short compared to the lives of my ancestors.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob blessed Pharaoh again before leaving his court.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph assigned the best land of Egypt—the region of Rameses—to his father and his brothers, and he settled them there, just as Pharaoh had commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Joseph provided food for his father and his brothers in amounts appropriate to the number of their dependents, including the smallest children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the famine became so severe that all the food was used up, and people were starving throughout the lands of Egypt and Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: By selling grain to the people, Joseph eventually collected all the money in Egypt and Canaan, and he put the money in Pharaoh’s treasury.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people of Egypt and Canaan ran out of money, all the Egyptians came to Joseph. “Our money is gone!” they cried. “But please give us food, or we will die before your very eyes!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph replied, “Since your money is gone, bring me your livestock. I will give you food in exchange for your livestock.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they brought their livestock to Joseph in exchange for food. In exchange for their horses, flocks of sheep and goats, herds of cattle, and donkeys, Joseph provided them with food for another year.
speaker: Narrator

text: But that year ended, and the next year they came again and said, “We cannot hide the truth from you, my lord. Our money is gone, and all our livestock and cattle are yours. We have nothing left to give but our bodies and our land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why should we die before your very eyes? Buy us and our land in exchange for food; we offer our land and ourselves as slaves for Pharaoh. Just give us grain so we may live and not die, and so the land does not become empty and desolate.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph bought all the land of Egypt for Pharaoh. All the Egyptians sold him their fields because the famine was so severe, and soon all the land belonged to Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the people, he made them all slaves, from one end of Egypt to the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: The only land he did not buy was the land belonging to the priests. They received an allotment of food directly from Pharaoh, so they didn’t need to sell their land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph said to the people, “Look, today I have bought you and your land for Pharaoh. I will provide you with seed so you can plant the fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then when you harvest it, one-fifth of your crop will belong to Pharaoh. You may keep the remaining four-fifths as seed for your fields and as food for you, your households, and your little ones.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You have saved our lives!” they exclaimed. “May it please you, my lord, to let us be Pharaoh’s servants.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph then issued a decree still in effect in the land of Egypt, that Pharaoh should receive one-fifth of all the crops grown on his land. Only the land belonging to the priests was not given to Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the people of Israel settled in the region of Goshen in Egypt. There they acquired property, and they were fruitful, and their population grew rapidly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob lived for seventeen years after his arrival in Egypt, so he lived 147 years in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the time of his death drew near, Jacob called for his son Joseph and said to him, “Please do me this favor. Put your hand under my thigh and swear that you will treat me with unfailing love by honoring this last request: Do not bury me in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I die, please take my body out of Egypt and bury me with my ancestors.”
So Joseph promised, “I will do as you ask.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Swear that you will do it,” Jacob insisted. So Joseph gave his oath, and Jacob bowed humbly at the head of his bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day not long after this, word came to Joseph, “Your father is failing rapidly.” So Joseph went to visit his father, and he took with him his two sons, Manasseh and Ephraim.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph arrived, Jacob was told, “Your son Joseph has come to see you.” So Jacob gathered his strength and sat up in his bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob said to Joseph, “God Almighty appeared to me at Luz in the land of Canaan and blessed me.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, ‘I will make you fruitful, and I will multiply your descendants. I will make you a multitude of nations. And I will give this land of Canaan to your descendants after you as an everlasting possession.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now I am claiming as my own sons these two boys of yours, Ephraim and Manasseh, who were born here in the land of Egypt before I arrived. They will be my sons, just as Reuben and Simeon are.
speaker: Narrator

text: But any children born to you in the future will be your own, and they will inherit land within the territories of their brothers Ephraim and Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Long ago, as I was returning from Paddan-aram, Rachel died in the land of Canaan. We were still on the way, some distance from Ephrath (that is, Bethlehem). So with great sorrow I buried her there beside the road to Ephrath.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob looked over at the two boys. “Are these your sons?” he asked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Yes,” Joseph told him, “these are the sons God has given me here in Egypt.”
And Jacob said, “Bring them closer to me, so I can bless them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob was half blind because of his age and could hardly see. So Joseph brought the boys close to him, and Jacob kissed and embraced them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob said to Joseph, “I never thought I would see your face again, but now God has let me see your children, too!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph moved the boys, who were at their grandfather’s knees, and he bowed with his face to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he positioned the boys in front of Jacob. With his right hand he directed Ephraim toward Jacob’s left hand, and with his left hand he put Manasseh at Jacob’s right hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob crossed his arms as he reached out to lay his hands on the boys’ heads. He put his right hand on the head of Ephraim, though he was the younger boy, and his left hand on the head of Manasseh, though he was the firstborn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he blessed Joseph and said,
“May the God before whom my grandfather Abraham
    and my father, Isaac, walked—
the God who has been my shepherd
    all my life, to this very day,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the Angel who has redeemed me from all harm—
    may he bless these boys.
May they preserve my name
    and the names of Abraham and Isaac.
And may their descendants multiply greatly
    throughout the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joseph was upset when he saw that his father placed his right hand on Ephraim’s head. So Joseph lifted it to move it from Ephraim’s head to Manasseh’s head.
speaker: Narrator

text: “No, my father,” he said. “This one is the firstborn. Put your right hand on his head.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But his father refused. “I know, my son; I know,” he replied. “Manasseh will also become a great people, but his younger brother will become even greater. And his descendants will become a multitude of nations.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob blessed the boys that day with this blessing: “The people of Israel will use your names when they give a blessing. They will say, ‘May God make you as prosperous as Ephraim and Manasseh.’” In this way, Jacob put Ephraim ahead of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob said to Joseph, “Look, I am about to die, but God will be with you and will take you back to Canaan, the land of your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: And beyond what I have given your brothers, I am giving you an extra portion of the land that I took from the Amorites with my sword and bow.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob called together all his sons and said, “Gather around me, and I will tell you what will happen to each of you in the days to come.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Come and listen, you sons of Jacob;
    listen to Israel, your father.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Reuben, you are my firstborn, my strength,
    the child of my vigorous youth.
    You are first in rank and first in power.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you are as unruly as a flood,
    and you will be first no longer.
For you went to bed with my wife;
    you defiled my marriage couch.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Simeon and Levi are two of a kind;
    their weapons are instruments of violence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May I never join in their meetings;
    may I never be a party to their plans.
For in their anger they murdered men,
    and they crippled oxen just for sport.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Judah, your brothers will praise you.
    You will grasp your enemies by the neck.
    All your relatives will bow before you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Judah, my son, is a young lion
    that has finished eating its prey.
Like a lion he crouches and lies down;
    like a lioness—who dares to rouse him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The scepter will not depart from Judah,
    nor the ruler’s staff from his descendants,
until the coming of the one to whom it belongs,
    the one whom all nations will honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He ties his foal to a grapevine,
    the colt of his donkey to a choice vine.
He washes his clothes in wine,
    his robes in the blood of grapes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His eyes are darker than wine,
    and his teeth are whiter than milk.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Issachar is a sturdy donkey,
    resting between two saddlepacks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he sees how good the countryside is
    and how pleasant the land,
he will bend his shoulder to the load
    and submit himself to hard labor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Dan will govern his people,
    like any other tribe in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Dan will be a snake beside the road,
    a poisonous viper along the path
that bites the horse’s hooves
    so its rider is thrown off.
speaker: Narrator

text: I trust in you for salvation, O Lord!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Gad will be attacked by marauding bands,
    but he will attack them when they retreat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Asher will dine on rich foods
    and produce food fit for kings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Naphtali is a doe set free
    that bears beautiful fawns.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Joseph is the foal of a wild donkey,
    the foal of a wild donkey at a spring—
    one of the wild donkeys on the ridge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Archers attacked him savagely;
    they shot at him and harassed him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But his bow remained taut,
    and his arms were strengthened
by the hands of the Mighty One of Jacob,
    by the Shepherd, the Rock of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May the God of your father help you;
    may the Almighty bless you
with the blessings of the heavens above,
    and blessings of the watery depths below,
    and blessings of the breasts and womb.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May my fatherly blessings on you
    surpass the blessings of my ancestors,
    reaching to the heights of the eternal hills.
May these blessings rest on the head of Joseph,
    who is a prince among his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Benjamin is a ravenous wolf,
    devouring his enemies in the morning
    and dividing his plunder in the evening.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the twelve tribes of Israel, and this is what their father said as he told his sons good-bye. He blessed each one with an appropriate message.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob instructed them, “Soon I will die and join my ancestors. Bury me with my father and grandfather in the cave in the field of Ephron the Hittite.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the cave in the field of Machpelah, near Mamre in Canaan, that Abraham bought from Ephron the Hittite as a permanent burial site.
speaker: Narrator

text: There Abraham and his wife Sarah are buried. There Isaac and his wife, Rebekah, are buried. And there I buried Leah.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is the plot of land and the cave that my grandfather Abraham bought from the Hittites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob had finished this charge to his sons, he drew his feet into the bed, breathed his last, and joined his ancestors in death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph threw himself on his father and wept over him and kissed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph told the physicians who served him to embalm his father’s body; so Jacob was embalmed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The embalming process took the usual forty days. And the Egyptians mourned his death for seventy days.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the period of mourning was over, Joseph approached Pharaoh’s advisers and said, “Please do me this favor and speak to Pharaoh on my behalf.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell him that my father made me swear an oath. He said to me, ‘Listen, I am about to die. Take my body back to the land of Canaan, and bury me in the tomb I prepared for myself.’ So please allow me to go and bury my father. After his burial, I will return without delay.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh agreed to Joseph’s request. “Go and bury your father, as he made you promise,” he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph went up to bury his father. He was accompanied by all of Pharaoh’s officials, all the senior members of Pharaoh’s household, and all the senior officers of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph also took his entire household and his brothers and their households. But they left their little children and flocks and herds in the land of Goshen.
speaker: Narrator

text: A great number of chariots and charioteers accompanied Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they arrived at the threshing floor of Atad, near the Jordan River, they held a very great and solemn memorial service, with a seven-day period of mourning for Joseph’s father.
speaker: Narrator

text: The local residents, the Canaanites, watched them mourning at the threshing floor of Atad. Then they renamed that place (which is near the Jordan) Abel-mizraim, for they said, “This is a place of deep mourning for these Egyptians.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob’s sons did as he had commanded them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They carried his body to the land of Canaan and buried him in the cave in the field of Machpelah, near Mamre. This is the cave that Abraham had bought as a permanent burial site from Ephron the Hittite.
speaker: Narrator

text: After burying Jacob, Joseph returned to Egypt with his brothers and all who had accompanied him to his father’s burial.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now that their father was dead, Joseph’s brothers became fearful. “Now Joseph will show his anger and pay us back for all the wrong we did to him,” they said.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they sent this message to Joseph: “Before your father died, he instructed us
speaker: Narrator

text: to say to you: ‘Please forgive your brothers for the great wrong they did to you—for their sin in treating you so cruelly.’ So we, the servants of the God of your father, beg you to forgive our sin.” When Joseph received the message, he broke down and wept.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his brothers came and threw themselves down before Joseph. “Look, we are your slaves!” they said.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joseph replied, “Don’t be afraid of me. Am I God, that I can punish you?
speaker: Narrator

text: You intended to harm me, but God intended it all for good. He brought me to this position so I could save the lives of many people.
speaker: Narrator

text: No, don’t be afraid. I will continue to take care of you and your children.” So he reassured them by speaking kindly to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph and his brothers and their families continued to live in Egypt. Joseph lived to the age of 110.
speaker: Narrator

text: He lived to see three generations of descendants of his son Ephraim, and he lived to see the birth of the children of Manasseh’s son Makir, whom he claimed as his own.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Soon I will die,” Joseph told his brothers, “but God will surely come to help you and lead you out of this land of Egypt. He will bring you back to the land he solemnly promised to give to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph made the sons of Israel swear an oath, and he said, “When God comes to help you and lead you back, you must take my bones with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph died at the age of 110. The Egyptians embalmed him, and his body was placed in a coffin in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator
